name: Hausdorff Non-compact
statement: $B^2$ and $A$ are Hausdorff and non-compact.
proof: According to the Heine-Borel theorem, a subset of $\\mathbb{R}^n$ is compact if and only if it is closed and bounded. $B^2$ and $A$ are bounded but open, so they are not compact. Furthermore, $\\mathbb{R}^n$ is metrisable (i.e. we can endow it with its usual metric space structure) and thus Hausdorff. It follows that all its subspaces are metrisable and Hausdorff.

name: Path-connectedness
statement: $B^2$ and $A$ are path-connected and therefore connected.
proof: We discuss path-connectedness in detail below, in Subsection 2.1.2. For now, just recall the definition (a space is path-connected if any two points can be connected via a continuous path), as well as the fact that being path-connected implies being connected (Lemma 2.9 below).\n\n$B^2$ is convex and therefore path-connected (Corollary 2.8 below). The annulus $A$ is neither convex nor star-shaped, but we can show that it is path-connected by hand. Namely, any point in $A$ can be connected via a radial path to a point in $S \\subset A$, the circle of radius $3/2$. It remains to show that $S$ is path-connected, which follows from the fact that any two points $\\frac{3}{2}e^{\\theta_0 i}, \\frac{3}{2}e^{\\theta_1 i} \\in S$ can be connected by a path that interpolates linearly between their angles.

name: Loop Non-contractibility
statement: Let $\\gamma : S^1 \\to A$ be the inclusion of the circle of radius $3/2$. This loop cannot be contracted to a constant map in a continuous way.
proof: The intuition is that any attempt to contract $\\gamma$ (by \
it\\: will result in the loop getting \
stuck\\: n the hole. The hole serves thus as an obstacle. See Figure 2.

name: Convex Contractibility
statement: Let $X \\subset \\mathbb{R}^n$ be convex. Any loop $\\nu : S^1 \\to X$ is homotopic (i.e. can be deformed continuously) to a constant map.
proof: Fix a point $x \\in X$ and consider the map $F(t, s) := (1 - s)\\nu(t) + sx$. This is a continuous map $F : S^1 \\times [0, 1] \\to X$, which we imagine as a \
movie\\: f maps $S^1 \\to X$. The first map in this movie is $F(t, 0) = \\nu(t)$. The last map $F(t, 1)$ is the constant loop with value $x$. We have therefore exhibited a continuous way of connecting the two.

name: Circle Homotopy Classes
statement: $[S^1, S^1] \\cong \\mathbb{Z}$.
proof: We do not have the tools to prove it yet. We will tackle it in Section 10.3. For now, it is sufficient that you have in mind the intuition that each homotopy class $[\\gamma] \\in [S^1, S^1]$ is identified, under this bijection, with the number of turns made by the curve $\\gamma : S^1 \\to S^1$.

name: Category Definition
statement:
A category $C$ is a tuple consisting of:

$\bullet$ A class $Ob(C)$ whose elements are called objects.
$\bullet$ For each pair of objects $x, y \in Ob(C)$, there is a class $Hom_C(x, y)$ whose elements are called the morphisms from $x$ to $y$.

$\bullet$ For each object $x \in Ob(C)$, there is a unique element $id_x \in Hom_C(x, x)$ called the identity at $x$.

$\bullet$ For each triple of objects $x, y, z \in Ob(C)$, there is a composition map

$\circ : Hom_C(x, y) \times Hom_C(y, z) \rightarrow Hom_C(x, z)$.

Given a morphism $f \in Hom_C(x, y)$ we often write it as $f : x \rightarrow y$. We also say that $x = s(f)$ is the source of $f$ and $y = t(f)$ is its target. Given another morphism $g$, with $s(g) = t(f)$, we say that $g$ is composable with $f$ and we write $g \circ f := \circ(f, g)$. We require that:

$\bullet$ The composition $\circ$ is associative. That is: $h \circ (g \circ f) = (h \circ g) \circ f$. This allows us to drop the parentheses.

$\bullet$ The identities behave like identities for the composition. That is: $f \circ id_x = f$ and $id_x \circ h = h$ for any $f$ and $h$ morphisms with $s(f) = t(h) = x$.

name: Category of Sets
statement: The first example of a category is $Set$. Its class of objects $Ob(Set)$ consists of all sets. The class $Hom_{Set}(x, y)$ consists of all functions from the set $x$ to the set $y$. Do note that, in this case, $Hom_{Set}(x, y)$ is in fact a set (namely, $y^x$). The morphism $id_x : x \\rightarrow x$ is the usual identity from $x$ to itself. The composition is the usual composition of functions.

name: Category of Groups
statement: Another important category is $Grp$. Its class of objects $Ob(Grp)$ contains all groups. The set $Hom_{Grp}(x, y)$ consists of all group homomorphisms from $x$ to $y$. The composition and the identity are inherited from $Set$, so they satisfy the required axioms.

name: Category of Abelian Groups
statement: A small variation of the previous example is the category of abelian groups $Ab$. Its objects $Ob(Ab)$ are the abelian groups and the morphisms $Hom_{Ab}(x, y)$ are the group homomorphisms from $x$ to $y$.

name: Category of Vector Spaces
statement: Given a field $F$ we can consider the category $Vect_F$ of $F$-vector spaces. Its objects $Ob(Vect_F)$ are $F$-vector spaces and the morphisms $Hom_{Vect_F}(x, y)$ are the $F$-linear maps from $x$ to $y$.

name: Category Top
statement: Lastly, we have the category Top. Its objects $\\text{Ob}(\\text{Top})$ are topological spaces and the morphisms $\\text{Hom}_{\\text{Top}}(x, y)$ are the continuous maps from $x$ to $y$.

name: Group as Category
statement: To illuminate the previous warning further, here is a familiar example. Suppose $G$ is a group. We can then form a category $C$ by setting $\\text{Ob}(C) := \\{p\\}$ and $\\text{Hom}_C(p, p) := G$. That is, $C$ has a single element whose morphisms are the group $G$. Group elements are thus morphisms and their product is interpreted to be the composition of morphisms. Since $G$ has an identity and the product is associative, the axioms of a category are verified. Observe that, as in the warning, we are not thinking of $p \\in \\text{Ob}(C)$ as a set. Similarly, we are calling the elements of $G = \\text{Hom}_C(p, p)$ \
morphisms\\: but it does not make sense to \

name: Isomorphisms
statement:
Let $C$ be a category. Let $A$, $B$ be objects in $C$ and $f : A \to B$ and $g : B \to A$ be morphisms. We say that:

$\bullet$ $g$ is a left-inverse of $f$ if $g \circ f = \text{id}_A$.
$\bullet$ $g$ is a right-inverse of $f$ if $f \circ g = \text{id}_B$.
$\bullet$ $g$ is the inverse of $f$ if it is both a right and a left inverse.
$\bullet$ $f$ is an isomorphism if it has an inverse.

name: Isomorphism Examples
statement:
Isomorphisms are:

$\bullet$ Bijections, in the category Set.
$\bullet$ Group isomorphisms, in Grp and Ab.
$\bullet$ Homeomorphisms, in Top.

Furthermore, in a group, seen as a category, all elements are isomorphisms.

name: Inverse Uniqueness
statement: Let $f : A \\to B$ and $g, h : B \\to A$ be morphisms. Suppose that $g$ is a left-inverse of $f$. Suppose that $h$ is a right-inverse of $f$. Then $g = h$.
proof: We compute $g = g \\circ \\text{id}_B = g \\circ (f \\circ h) = (g \\circ f) \\circ h = \\text{id}_A \\circ h = h$.

name: Inverses in Set
statement: In $\\text{Set}$, a morphism $f : A \\to B$ is injective if and only if it has a left-inverse (which is itself surjective). Dually, $f$ is surjective if and only if it has a right-inverse.

name: Functor
statement:
Let $C$ and $D$ be categories. A (covariant) functor $F : C \to D$ consists of:

$\bullet$ A function $\text{Ob}(C) \to \text{Ob}(D)$, which we still denote by $F$.
$\bullet$ For each pair of objects $x, y \in \text{Ob}(C)$, a function $\text{Hom}_C(x, y) \to \text{Hom}_D(F(x), F(y))$.

Given $f \in \text{Hom}_C(x, y)$ we denote its image by $F(f) \in \text{Hom}_D(F(x), F(y))$. The following properties must hold:

$\bullet$ Given $x \in \text{Ob}(C)$, it holds that $F(\text{id}_x) = \text{id}_{F(x)}$.
$\bullet$ Given objects $x, y, z \in \text{Ob}(C)$ and morphisms $f : x \to y$ and $g : y \to z$, it holds that $F(g \circ f) = F(g) \circ F(f)$.

name: Group Functors
statement: Suppose that $G$ and $H$ are groups. As in Example 1.7, we can regard $G$ and $H$ as categories with a single object. Then, there is a bijection between group homomorphisms $G \\to H$ and functors from $G$ to $H$, seen as categories.

name: Forgetful Functor
statement: Consider the category $\\text{Top}$ of topological spaces. We can define a functor $F : \\text{Top} \\to \\text{Set}$ into the category of sets as follows. Every topological space $A$ is in particular a set, so we can let $F(A) \\in \\text{Ob}(\\text{Set})$ be the set underlying $A$. Similarly, we can forget that a map between topological spaces $f : A \\to B$ is continuous and simply see it as a function $F(A) \\to F(B)$. We denote this function by $F(f)$. It is clear that the identity and composition properties are preserved, so $F$ is indeed a functor. We often say that it is a forgetful functor, because we are forgetting the topological structure.

name: Category Forgetful Functors
statement: The previous reasoning works in any category whose objects are sets with extra structure and whose morphisms are functions respecting that structure. I.e. there are also forgetful functors from $\\text{Grp}$ and $\\text{Ab}$ into $\\text{Set}$.\n\nSimilarly, there is a forgetful functor $\\text{Ab} \\to \\text{Grp}$; this amounts to forgetting the fact that an abelian group is abelian. You can think of this as \

name: Functor Preserves Isomorphisms
statement:
Let $F : C \rightarrow D$ be a functor.

- Let $f : a \rightarrow b$ and $g : b \rightarrow a$ be morphisms in $C$. Suppose that $g \circ f = id_a$. Then $F(g) \circ F(f) = id_{F(a)}$.

- Suppose $f$ is an isomorphism. Then $F(f)$ is an isomorphism.
proof:
The first property is immediate from the fact that $F$ preserves the composition and the identities:

$F(g) \circ F(f) = F(g \circ f) = F(id_a) = id_{F(a)}$.

This implies that left and right inverses are preserved by $F$. This implies the second item.

name: Homotopic Maps
statement:
Two maps $f, g : A \rightarrow B$ are homotopic to each other if there is a homotopy between them. That is, a map $F : A \times [0, 1] \rightarrow B$ such that $f(a) = F(a, 0)$ and $g(a) = F(a, 1)$.

It is common to think of $F$ as a family/movie of maps $f_t : A \rightarrow B$ parametrised by the interval $[0, 1]$. These functions are given by the formula $f_t(a) := F(a, t)$.

Do note that a homotopy $F$ is more that just a family of (continuous) functions $(f_t = F(-, t))_{t\in[0,1]}$. It is crucial that $F$ is also continuous in the $t$-variable. This continuity in $t$ is precisely what we mean by \
continuously\\: eforming a map. If you imagine $f_t$ as a \
movie\\: f maps, continuity in $t$ means that there are no sudden \

name: Homotopy Equivalence Relation
statement: Being homotopic is an equivalence relation.

name: Constant Homotopy
statement: Let $f : A \\rightarrow B$ be a map. The constant homotopy $F : A \\times [0, 1] \\rightarrow B$ associated to $f$ is $F(a, t) := f(a)$.

name: Homotopy Reflexivity
statement: Being homotopic is a reflexive relation.
proof: Let $f : A \\rightarrow B$ be a map and let $F : A \\times [0, 1] \\rightarrow B$ be $F(a, t) = f(a)$. We claim that $F$ is continuous because it is a composition of continuous functions. Indeed, the projection to the first factor $\\pi_A : A \\times [0, 1] \\rightarrow A$ is continuous and so is $f$ by assumption. We conclude by writing $F = f \\circ \\pi_A$.\n\nSince $F(a, 0) = F(a, 1) = f(a)$ we see that $F$ is a homotopy from $f$ to itself, proving reflexivity.

name: Reverse Homotopy
statement: Let $F : A \\times [0, 1] \\to B$ be a homotopy. The reverse homotopy $\\overline{F} : A \\times [0, 1] \\to B$ is $\\overline{F}(a, t) := F(a, 1 - t)$.

name: Homotopy Symmetry
statement: Being homotopic is a symmetric relation.
proof: Let $F : A \\times [0, 1] \\to B$ be a homotopy from $f$ to $g$. We claim that its reverse $\\overline{F}$ is a homotopy from $g$ to $f$. We readily verify $\\overline{F}(a, 0) = F(a, 1) = g(a)$ and $\\overline{F}(a, 1) = F(a, 0) = f(a)$. It remains to prove that $\\overline{F}$ is continuous. We write $\\overline{F} = F \\circ (\\text{id}_A, \\rho)$ with $\\rho : [0, 1] \\to [0, 1]$ the map $t \\mapsto 1 - t$ that reverses the interval, which is continuous. The product $(\\text{id}_A, \\rho)$ of continuous maps is continuous, and thus $\\overline{F}$ is a composition of continuous maps.

name: Concatenable Homotopies
statement:
A homotopy $F : A \times [0, 1] \to B$ is concatenable with a homotopy $G : A \times [0, 1] \to B$ if $F(a, 1) = G(a, 0)$.

Suppose $F$ is concatenable with $G$. Then, the concatenation of $F$ with $G$ is defined as:

$G \bullet F(a, t) = \begin{cases} F(a, 2t) & \text{for } t \in [0, 1/2] \\ G(a, 2t - 1) & \text{for } t \in [1/2, 1] \end{cases}$

name: Homotopy Transitivity
statement: Being homotopic is a transitive relation.
proof: Suppose $f, g, h : A \\to B$ are maps such that $F$ is a homotopy from $f$ to $g$ and $G$ is a homotopy from $g$ to $h$. Then, the concatenation $G \\bullet F$ is a homotopy from $f$ to $h$, proving transitivity.\n\nBy construction we have $G \\bullet F(a, 0) = F(a, 0) = f$ and $G \\bullet F(a, 1) = G(a, 1) = h$, so it only remains to prove continuity. This follows from the pasting Lemma 1.25. We check its hypotheses: Over $A \\times [0, 1/2]$, the concatenation $G \\bullet F$ is given by $F(a, 2t)$, which is continuous (it is the composition of $F$ and $(\\text{id}_A, t \\mapsto 2t)$). Over $A \\times [1/2, 1]$, it is given by $G(a, 2t - 1)$, which is continuous for the same reasons. These two definitions agree in the overlap $A \\times \\{1/2\\}$, since either definition yields $G \\bullet F(a, 1/2) = g(a)$. The pasting lemma applies, proving the claim.

name: Pasting Lemma
statement: Let $A$ be a topological space presented as a finite union $A = \\cup_i B_i$ of (not necessarily disjoint) subspaces, all of them closed or all of them open. Then, a function $f : A \\to C$ is continuous if and only if $f|_{B_i}$ is continuous for all $i$.

name: Homotopy Class
statement:
Let $A$ and $B$ be spaces. Given a map $f : A \to B$, we denote by $[f]$ its equivalence class according to the homotopy equivalence relation. We say that $[f]$ is a homotopy class and that $f$ is a representative of the class.

The set of all homotopy classes of maps is denoted by

$[A, B] := \{[f] | f : A \to B \text{ map } \}$.

Recall that $\text{Hom}_{\text{Top}}(A, B)$ denotes the set of all maps from $A$ to $B$, so $[A, B]$ is its quotient by the homotopy equivalence relation.

name: Star-shaped Subspace
statement: A subspace $B \\subset \\mathbb{R}^n$ is star-shaped if there is a point $c \\in B$ such that, for every $b \\in B$, the straight segment $[b, c]$ is contained in $B$.\n\nIf $c \\in B$ is as in the definition, we will say that $c$ is a central point for $B$. Do note that such a $c$ is not unique in general.

name: Star-shaped Homotopy
statement:
Suppose that $B \subset \mathbb{R}^n$ is star-shaped. Let $A$ be a topological space. Then:

$\bullet$ Any map $f : A \to B$ is homotopic to a constant map.
$\bullet$ Any two maps $f, g : A \to B$ are homotopic to each other.
$\bullet$ $[A, B]$ consists of a single element.
proof: We will prove that any map $f : A \\to B$ is homotopic to the constant map with value $p \\in B$, where $p$ is a central point in $B$. This implies the three statements, the second one following from the transitivity of the homotopy relation. To prove the claim, consider the homotopy $F(a, t) := f(a)(1-t) + tp$. The continuity of $F$ follows by writing it as $F = G \\circ H$, with $H : A \\times [0, 1] \\to B \\times \\mathbb{R}$ given by $(a, t) \\mapsto (f(a), t)$, whose entries are continuous, and $G : B \\times \\mathbb{R} \\to B$ given by $(x, t) \\mapsto x(1-t) + tp$, which is a polynomial map. We also verify $F(a, 0) = f(a)$ and $F(a, 1) = p$.

name: Nullhomotopic Map
statement: Let $A, B$ be topological spaces. Fix an element $b \\in B$. We write $c_b : A \\to B$ for the constant map $c_b(a) := b$.\n\nA map $f : A \\to B$ is nullhomotopic if it is homotopic to a constant map.

name: Non-homotopic Constants
statement: Let $A = \\{p\\}$ and $B = \\{a, b\\}$, both endowed with the discrete topology. There are two maps $A \\to B$, namely $c_a$ and $c_b$. Both of them are constant and thus nullhomotopic.\n\nHowever, they are not homotopic to one another. It follows that $[A, B] = \\{[c_a], [c_b]\\}$ has also two elements.

name: Nullhomotopic Star-shaped Maps
statement: Suppose $B \\subset \\mathbb{R}^n$ is star-shaped. Let $A$ be a topological space. Then any map $f : B \\to A$ is nullhomotopic.
proof: Let $p \\in B$ be a central point. Given a map $f : B \\to A$, we consider the homotopy $F(a, t) := f(a(1-t) + tp)$. We write $F$ as $F = f \\circ H$, with $H : B \\times [0, 1] \\to B$ given by $(a, t) \\mapsto a(1-t) + tp$ polynomial, so $F$ is continuous. We also verify $F(a, 0) = f(a)$ and $F(a, 1) = f(p)$.

name: Point Maps Bijection
statement: Let $A$ be a topological space. Then, there is a bijection: $A \\to \\text{Hom}_{\\text{Top}}(\\{p\\}, A)$ given by $a \\mapsto c_a$.
proof: This result does not require a proof as it follows directly from the definition of maps from a point. The bijection maps each element $a \\in A$ to the constant map $c_a: \\{p\\} \\to A$ that sends the point $p$ to $a$.

name: Homotopy-Path Equivalence
statement: A homotopy between $c_a$ and $c_b$ is equivalent to a path $\\gamma : [0, 1] \\to A$ starting at $a = \\gamma(0)$ and finishing at $b = \\gamma(1)$.
proof:
Given a homotopy $F: \{p\} \times [0,1] \to A$ between $c_a$ and $c_b$, we have $F(p,0) = a$ and $F(p,1) = b$. We can define a path $\gamma: [0,1] \to A$ by $\gamma(t) = F(p,t)$. This gives us a path from $a$ to $b$.

Conversely, given a path $\gamma: [0,1] \to A$ from $a$ to $b$, we can define a homotopy $F: \{p\} \times [0,1] \to A$ by $F(p,t) = \gamma(t)$. This gives us a homotopy between $c_a$ and $c_b$.

The correspondence is bijective because we can use the homeomorphism $[0,1] \to \{p\} \times [0,1]$ given by $t \mapsto (p,t)$ to transfer between the two structures.

name: Path-components
statement:
Let $A$ be a space. We introduce the following equivalence relation: two points $a, b \in A$ are related $a \sim b$ if there is a path from $a$ to $b$.

• Each equivalence class is said to be a path-component.
• The set of path-components of $A$ is denoted by $\pi_0(A)$.
• If $A$ has a single path-component, we say that $A$ is path-connected.

name: Path-components Bijection
statement: Let $A$ be a topological space. Then, there is a bijection: $\\pi_0(A) \\to [\\{p\\}, A]$ given by $[a] \\mapsto [c_a]$.
proof: According to Lemma 2.4, there is a bijection $A \\cong \\text{Hom}_{\\text{Top}}(\\{p\\}, A)$. On the right we are relating maps if they are homotopic. On the left we are relating points if they can be connected by a path. These two relations correspond to one another according to Lemma 2.5, proving the claim.\n\nIn particular, note that being homotopic is an equivalence relation (Proposition 1.18). From this, it follows that the relation given in Definition 2.6 is indeed an equivalence relation.

name: Star-shaped Path-connectedness
statement: Suppose $A \\subset \\mathbb{R}^n$ is star-shaped. Then $\\pi_0(A) \\cong \\{.\\}$.
proof: This follows from the fact that star-shaped sets are path-connected, as any two points can be connected by straight line segments through the central point.

name: Path-connected Implies Connected
statement: A path-connected space $X$ is connected.
proof: Consider a partition $X = Y \\sqcup Z$, with $Y$ and $Z$ both open. If both are non-empty, we can find points $y \\in Y$ and $z \\in Z$. We can then use path-connectedness to find a path $\\gamma : [0, 1] \\to X$ starting at $y$ and finishing at $z$. The subsets $\\gamma^{-1}(Y)$ and $\\gamma^{-1}(Z)$ partition $[0, 1]$ and are open (by continuity of $\\gamma$). This is a contradiction with the fact that $[0, 1]$ is connected. It follows that $Y$ or $Z$ had to be empty, implying that $X$ is itself connected.

name: Union Path-connectedness
statement:
Let $X = \cup U_i$ be a topological space presented as a finite union of subspaces. Suppose that:

$\bullet$ All $U_i$ are path-connected.
$\bullet$ For every pair of indices $i$ and $j$, there is a sequence of indices

$i = i_0, i_1, i_2, \cdot \cdot \cdot, i_n = j$

verifying $U_{i_k} \cap U_{i_{k+1}} \neq \emptyset$ for all $k = 0, \cdot \cdot \cdot, n - 1$.

Then, $X$ is path-connected.
proof: Given any two points $x, y \\in X$, we want to exhibit a path between them. We have that $x$ is contained in some $U_i$ and $y$ in some $U_j$. Let $i_0, i_1, i_2, \\cdot \\cdot \\cdot, i_n$ be a sequence from $i$ to $j$ given by the second hypothesis. We can fix points $x_{i_k} \\in U_{i_k} \\cap U_{i_{k+1}}$. The first hypothesis then says that there is a path from $x$ to $x_{i_0}$ (because $U_{i_0}$ is path-connected), a path between $x_{i_k}$ and $x_{i_{k+1}}$ (because $U_{i_{k+1}}$ is path-connected) for each $k$, and a path from $x_{i_n}$ to $y$. All these paths can be concatenated to produce the claimed path from $x$ to $y$.

name: Homotopy Category
statement:
The (naive) homotopy category of topological spaces, which we denote hTop:

$\bullet$ Has the same objects as Top. I.e. $\text{Ob}(\text{hTop}) := \text{Ob}(\text{Top})$.
$\bullet$ Its morphisms are homotopy classes of maps. I.e. for any two spaces $A$ and $B$, we set

$\text{Hom}_{\text{hTop}}(A, B) := [A, B]$.

$\bullet$ The identity at $A \in \text{Ob}(\text{hTop})$ is the homotopy class $[\text{id}_A]$ of the identity map.
$\bullet$ The composition of morphisms is defined by composing representatives. I.e.

$\circ : \text{Hom}_{\text{hTop}}(A, B) \times \text{Hom}_{\text{hTop}}(B, C) \to \text{Hom}_{\text{Top}}(A, C)$

$([f], [g]) \mapsto [g] \circ [f] := [g \circ f]$.

name: Well-defined Composition
statement: The composition is well-defined.
proof: We must check that the composition does not depend on the choice of representatives. That is, suppose that there are maps $f, f' : A \\to B$ and $g, g' : B \\to C$ such that $[f'] = [f]$ and $[g'] = [g]$. This means that there is a homotopy $F$ between $f$ and $f'$ and a homotopy $G$ from $g$ to $g'$. We claim that $H(a, t) := G(F(a, t), t)$ is a homotopy between $g \\circ f$ and $g' \\circ f'$, proving that $[g \\circ f] = [g' \\circ f']$, as desired.\n\nFirst note that $H(a, 0) = G(F(a, 0), 0) = g \\circ f(a)$. Similarly $H(a, 1) = G(F(a, 1), 1) = g' \\circ f'(a)$. Lastly, $H$ is a composition of continuous functions and thus continuous.

name: Composition Associativity
statement: The composition is associative.
proof: Associativity for the composition of homotopy classes follows from associativity at the level of representatives:\n\n$([g] \\circ [f]) \\circ [h] = [g \\circ f] \\circ [h] = [g \\circ f \\circ h] = [g] \\circ [f \\circ h] = [g] \\circ ([f] \\circ [h]).$

name: Identity Morphism
statement: Let $A$ be a space. Then $[id_A]$ is the identity, in $hTop$, at the object $A$.
proof:
Given maps $f: A \to B$ and $g: B \to A$ we have:

$[f] \circ [id_A] = [f \circ id_A] = [f]$,

$[id_A] \circ [g] = [id_A \circ g] = [g]$.

name: Homotopy Equivalence
statement:
A map $f: A \to B$ is a homotopy equivalence if there is a map $g: B \to A$ such that

$\bullet$ $g \circ f$ is homotopic to $id_A$.
$\bullet$ $f \circ g$ is homotopic to $id_B$.

Then, we say that $f$ and $g$ are homotopy inverses and that $A$ and $B$ are homotopy equivalent.

name: Uniqueness Homotopy
statement: Let $f: A \\to B$ be a map. Suppose that $g, h: B \\to A$ are homotopy inverses of $f$. Then $[g] = [h]$.
proof: $f$ is a homotopy equivalence iff $[f]$ is an isomorphism in $hTop$. Inverses are unique in any category (Lemma 1.10), so the inverse of $[f]$ (which in this case exists) is unique. It follows that $[g] = [f]^{-1} = [h]$.

name: Equivalence Relation
statement: Homotopy equivalence is an equivalence relation.
proof: Being homotopy equivalent simply means being isomorphic in $hTop$. The result then follows from the fact that being isomorphic (in any category) is a equivalence relation.

name: Homeomorphism Homotopy Equivalence
statement: A homeomorphism is a homotopy equivalence.
proof: This follows from the fact that a continuous inverse is in particular a homotopy inverse. More categorically, you could instead say that the quotient functor $\\text{Top} \\to \\text{hTop}$ takes isomorphisms to isomorphisms.

name: Contractible Space
statement: A space $A$ is contractible if it is homotopy equivalent to $\\{.\\}$ (the set with one point).

name: Star-shaped Contractibility
statement: Any $X \\subset \\mathbb{R}^n$ star-shaped is contractible.
proof: Consider the unique constant map $f : X \\to \\{.\\}$ and an inclusion $g : \\{.\\} \\to X$. It trivially follows that $f \\circ g = \\text{id}_{\\{.\\}}$ so, upon taking homotopy classes, $[f]$ is a left-inverse of $[g]$. Conversely, since $[X, X] = \\{[\\text{id}_X]\\}$ (Lemma 1.28) we deduce that $[g \\circ f] = [\\text{id}_X]$ and thus $[f]$ is a right-inverse of $[g]$. We conclude that $f$ and $g$ are homotopy inverses.

name: Pushforward
statement:
Let $C$ be a category, $w, x, y$ objects in $C$ and $g : x \to y$ a morphism. The pushforward of $g$ is the function:

$g_* : \text{Hom}_C(w, x) \to \text{Hom}_C(w, y)$

$h \mapsto g_*(h) := g \circ h$.

Do note that $g$ defines a pushforward for each object $w \in C$, but we omit it from the notation $g_*$. For this reason, it is important to specify what the domain of $g_*$ is.

name: Pushforward Composition
statement: Let $C$ be a category, $x, y, z$ objects in $C$ and $g : x \\to y$ and $f : y \\to z$ morphisms. Then, for any other object $w \\in C$, the pushforwards $f_*$ and $g_*$ satisfy:\n\n$(f \\circ g)_* = f_* \\circ g_*$.
proof: This follows from the fact that both maps, when applied to $h : w \\to x$, yield $f \\circ g \\circ h$.

name: Pushforward Inverse Preservation
statement:
Let $f$, $g$, and $h$ be morphisms in $C$. Then:

• If $f$ is a left-inverse of $g$, then $f_*$ is a left-inverse of $g_*$.
• If $f$ is a right-inverse of $h$, then $f_*$ is a right-inverse of $h_*$.
proof: This follows directly from the properties of the pushforward and composition of morphisms. If $f$ is a left-inverse of $g$, then $f \\circ g = \\text{id}$. Applying the pushforward, we get $f_* \\circ g_* = (f \\circ g)_* = \\text{id}_*$, which means $f_*$ is a left-inverse of $g_*$. Similarly for the right-inverse case.

name: Isomorphism Bijection
statement: Suppose $f : y \\to z$ is an isomorphism. Then $f_* : \\text{Hom}_C(x, y) \\to \\text{Hom}_C(x, z)$ is a bijection, for all $x \\in C$.
proof: Since $f$ is an isomorphism, it has an inverse $f^{-1}$ such that $f \\circ f^{-1} = \\text{id}_z$ and $f^{-1} \\circ f = \\text{id}_y$. By Corollary 2.24, $f_*$ is a right-inverse of $(f^{-1})_*$ and $(f^{-1})_*$ is a right-inverse of $f_*$. This means $f_* \\circ (f^{-1})_* = \\text{id}$ and $(f^{-1})_* \\circ f_* = \\text{id}$, making $f_*$ a bijection.

name: Right-Inverse Equivalence
statement:
The following are equivalent:

a. $f : y \to z$ has a right-inverse.
b. $f_* : \text{Hom}_C(x, y) \to \text{Hom}_C(x, z)$ is surjective, for all $x \in C$.
c. $f_* : \text{Hom}_C(z, y) \to \text{Hom}_C(z, z)$ is surjective.
proof:
Item (a) implies item (b) by Corollary 2.24.

Item (c) is a particular case of (b).

To show that (c) implies (a), observe that $\text{Hom}_C(z, z)$ contains the map $\text{id}_z$, and $f_*$ being surjective means that there is a map $g \in \text{Hom}_C(z, y)$ such that $f \circ g = f_*(g) = \text{id}_z$. I.e. $g$ is a right-inverse of $f$.

name: Pullback
statement:
Let $C$ be a category, $x$, $y$, $z$ objects in $C$ and $g : x \to y$ a morphism. The pullback of $g$ is the function:

$g^* : \text{Hom}_C(y, z) \to \text{Hom}_C(x, z)$

$f \mapsto g^*(f) := f \circ g$.

name: Pullback Composition
statement: Let $C$ be a category, $w$, $x$, $y$ objects in $C$ and $h : w \\to x$ and $g : x \\to y$ morphisms. Then, for any other object $z \\in C$, the pullbacks $g^*$ and $h^*$ satisfy:\n\n$(g \\circ h)^* = h^* \\circ g^*$.
proof: Both sides, when applied to $f : y \\to z$, yield $f \\circ g \\circ h$.

name: Pullback Inverse Properties
statement:
Let $f$, $g$, and $h$ be morphisms in $C$. Then:

• If $f$ is a left-inverse of $g$, then $f^*$ is a right-inverse of $g^*$.
• If $f$ is a right-inverse of $h$, then $f^*$ is a left-inverse of $h^*$.
proof: This is stated without proof in the text.

name: Pullback Bijection
statement: Suppose $f : y \\to z$ is an isomorphism. Then $f^* : \\text{Hom}_C(z, x) \\to \\text{Hom}_C(y, x)$ is a bijection, for all $x \\in C$.
proof: This is stated without proof in the text.

name: Left-Inverse Characterization
statement:
The following are equivalent:

a. $f : y \to z$ has a left-inverse.
b. $f^* : \text{Hom}_C(z, x) \to \text{Hom}_C(y, x)$ is surjective, for all $x \in C$.
c. $f^* : \text{Hom}_C(z, y) \to \text{Hom}_C(y, y)$ is surjective.
proof: This is left as an exercise for the reader in the text.

name: Isomorphism Criterion
statement: Let $f : y \\to z$ be a morphism such that $f_*$ and $f^*$ are bijections for all $x \\in C$. Then $f$ is an isomorphism.
proof: According to Lemma 2.26, $f_*$ being surjective, means that $f$ has a right-inverse. Similarly, Lemma 2.31 says that $f$ has a left-inverse because $f^*$ is surjective. It follows that $f$ is invertible by Lemma 1.10.

name: Homotopy Pushforward
statement: Given a map $f : B \\to C$ in Top, we write $f_* := [f]_* : [A, B] \\to [A, C]$ for its pushforward at the level of homotopy classes.\n\nDo note that this is different from the pushforward $f_* : \\text{Hom}_{\\text{Top}}(A, B) \\to \\text{Hom}_{\\text{Top}}(A, C)$ in Top, which takes a map $g$ to $f \\circ g$ (i.e. no homotopy classes here!).

name: Pullback Definition
statement: Given a map $f : B \\to C$ in Top, we write $f^* := [f]_* : [C, A] \\to [B, A]$ for its pullback at the level of homotopy classes.

name: Homotopy Equivalence Criterion
statement:
A map $f : B \to C$ in Top is a homotopy equivalence if and only if:

$\bullet$ $f_* : [A, B] \to [A, C]$ is a bijection and,
$\bullet$ $f^* : [C, A] \to [B, A]$ is a bijection,

for all $A \in \text{Top}$.

name: Contractible Space Properties
statement:
If $B \in \text{Top}$ is contractible then it holds, for any $A$:

$\bullet$ $[A, B] \cong \{.\}$ for all $A$.
$\bullet$ $[B, A] \cong \pi_0(A)$.
proof: The statement is true if $B$ is the point. For any other contractible $B$, we can apply the previous corollary using the fact that $B$ and the point are isomorphic.

name: Path-component Invariance
statement: Let $B$ and $C$ be homotopy equivalent spaces. Then, $\\pi_0(B) \\cong \\pi_0(C)$.

name: Contractibility Equivalences
statement:
The following conditions are equivalent for a space $X$:

i. $X$ is contractible.
ii. $[A, X]$ consists of a single element, for all spaces $A$.
iii. $[X, X]$ consists of a single element.
iv. $\text{id}_X$ is nullhomotopic.
proof: Item (i) implies (ii) according to Corollary 2.36. Item (iii) is a concrete instance of (ii). According to Item (iii), any two maps from $X$ to $X$ are homotopic; in particular, this is true for $\\text{id}_X$ and any constant map. To see that (iv) implies (i), we consider the unique map $c_p : X \\to \\{p\\}$ and the constant map $c_x : \\{p\\} \\to X$ with value $x \\in X$. We have that $c_p \\circ c_x = \\text{id}_{\\{p\\}}$. Conversely, $c_x \\circ c_p : X \\to X$ is the constant map with value $x$, which is homotopic to the identity. It follows that $c_x$ and $c_p$ are homotopy inverses.

name: Annulus-Circle Equivalence
statement: The annulus $A$ and the circle are homotopy equivalent.
proof: We can use polar coordinates $(r, \\theta)$ in $\\mathbb{R}^2$. Then $S^1 = \\{r = 3/2\\}$ (note that any two circles are homeomorphic) and $A = \\{1 < r < 2\\}$. We let $f : S^1 \\to A$ be the inclusion and $g : A \\to S^1$ be given by $g(r, \\theta) = (3/2, \\theta)$. Then $g \\circ f = \\text{id}_{S^1}$. Furthermore, $f \\circ g(r, \\theta) = (3/2, \\theta)$ is homotopic to the identity thanks to $(r, \\theta; t) \\mapsto (tr + (1 - t)3/2, \\theta)$, which amounts to interpolating linearly in the radius. See Figure 3.1.

name: Annulus Homotopy Classes
statement: $[A, A] \\cong [S^1, S^1] \\cong \\mathbb{Z}$
proof: According to Corollary 2.35, when evaluating $[-,-]$, we can replace each entry by a homotopy equivalent space without changing the result (up to isomorphism). We thus apply Lemma 3.3 to replace $A$ by $S^1$, proving the first equality. The second equality is Theorem 3.2.

name: Non-contractibility Results
statement: The annulus and $S^1$ are not contractible. In particular, the annulus is not homotopy equivalent to the ball $B^2$.
proof: Since $[S^1, S^1] \\cong [S^1, A] \\cong \\mathbb{Z}$ (Theorem 3.2), we deduce from Corollary 2.36 that they cannot be homotopy equivalent to a point. In contrast, the ball is convex and thus contractible.

name: Retraction
statement: Let $C$ be a category. A morphism $r : x \\to y$ is a retraction if it has a right-inverse $\\iota : y \\to x$. Then we say that $y$ is a retract of $x$.

name: Group Retraction
statement: Let $\\iota : H \\to G$ be an injective homomorphism of groups. If $\\iota$ is a right inverse of some $r : G \\to H$, we can consider the kernel $K := \\ker(r) \\subset G$ and, by the first isomorphism theorem, we have that $H \\cong G/K$. This means that $G$ is the semidirect product of $H$ and $K$.

name: Inclusion Property
statement: Suppose $r : X \\to Y$ is a retraction and $\\iota : Y \\to X$ is a right-inverse. Then $\\iota$ is an inclusion (i.e. a homeomorphism with its image).
proof: Seeing $\\iota$ as a map $Y \\to \\iota(Y)$, we see that $r|_{\\iota(Y)}$ is a continuous inverse.

name: Point Retraction
statement: Let $A$ be a topological space and $a \\in A$ a point. Then, $\\{a\\}$ is a retract of $A$.
proof: It is immediate that the unique map $r : A \\to \\{a\\}$ is a left-inverse to the inclusion.

name: Retraction Properties
statement:
Let $A$, $B$ and $C$ be topological spaces. Suppose that $\iota : B \to C$ is an inclusion and $r : C \to B$ is a retraction serving as a left-inverse. Then:

• $r_* : [A, C] \to [A, B]$ is a left-inverse of $\iota_* : [A, B] \to [A, C]$.

• In particular, $r_*$ is surjective and $\iota_*$ is injective.
• $r^* : [B, A] \to [C, A]$ is a right-inverse of $\iota^* : [C, A] \to [B, A]$.
• In particular, $r^*$ is injective and $\iota^*$ is surjective.

name: Non-retractable Inclusions
statement: Not every inclusion $\\iota$ is a right-inverse of a retraction.
proof:
Consider the inclusion $\iota : \{0, 1\} \to \mathbb{R}$. Suppose that there is a retraction $r : \mathbb{R} \to \{0, 1\}$. Then we would have a surjection

$r_* : [\{.\}, \mathbb{R}] \to [\{.\}, \{0, 1\}]$.

However, this is not possible, since the domain is the singleton set and the target has two elements.

More generally, let $\iota : A \to B$ be an inclusion such that $\iota_* : \pi_0(A) \to \pi_0(B)$ is not injective. I.e. one of the path-components of $B$ contains more than one path-component of $A$. Then, $A$ cannot be a retract of $B$.

name: Circle Non-retract
statement: $S^1$ is not a retract of $\\mathbb{R}^2$.
proof: Suppose for contradiction that we can find an inclusion $\\iota : S^1 \\to \\mathbb{R}^2$ (which need not be the standard one) and a retraction $r : \\mathbb{R}^2 \\to S^1$ left-inverting $\\iota$. Then, the pushforward $r_* : [S^1, \\mathbb{R}^2] \\to [S^1, S^1]$ is surjective and $\\iota_*$ is injective. This contradicts the fact that $[S^1, \\mathbb{R}^2] \\simeq \\{.\\}$ and $[S^1, S^1] \\simeq \\mathbb{Z}$ (Theorem 3.2).

name: Deformation Retract
statement: Let $A$ be a space and $B \\subset A$ a retract. We write $\\iota$ and $r$ for the inclusion and the retraction, respectively. We say that $B$ is a deformation retract if there is a homotopy $(f_t)_{t\\in[0,1]} : A \\to A$ such that $f_0 = \\text{id}_A$, $f_1 = \\iota \\circ r$, and $f_t|_B = \\text{id}_B$ for all $t$. We then say that $r$ is a deformation retraction.

name: Circle Deformation Retract
statement: The circle of radius $3/2$ is a deformation retract of the annulus $A$.

name: Sphere Deformation Retract
statement: The sphere $S^{n-1}$, included in the standard manner in $\\mathbb{R}^n$, is a deformation retract of $\\mathbb{R}^n \\setminus \\{0\\}$.
proof: The map $r(x) = x/|x|$ is a retraction $r : \\mathbb{R}^n \\setminus \\{0\\} \\to S^{n-1}$, since it keeps unit vectors fixed. The linear homotopy $(r_t)_{t\\in[0,1]} : \\mathbb{R}^n \\setminus \\{0\\} \\to S^{n-1}$ given by $r_t(x) = (1 - t)x + tr(x)$ provides the desired deformation retraction.

name: Covariant Hom-Functor
statement:
Fix a category$^1$ $C$ and an object $x$. Using this data, we define a functor $F = \text{Hom}_C(x, -) : C \to \text{Set}$ as follows:

$\bullet$ Given $y \in \text{Ob}(C)$, we map it to $F(y) := \text{Hom}_C(x, y)$.
$\bullet$ Given objects $y, z \in \text{Ob}(C)$, we take a morphism $f : y \to z$ to $F(f) : \text{Hom}_C(x, y) \to \text{Hom}_C(x, z)$ by setting $F(f)(g) := f_*g = f \circ g$.

We say that $\text{Hom}_C(x, -)$ is the covariant hom-functor associated to $x$.

name: Covariant Hom-Functor Well-Defined
statement: The functor $F = \\text{Hom}_C(x, -) : C \\to \\text{Set}$ is well-defined.
proof:
The composition axiom holds: Indeed, given morphisms $f : y \to z$ and $g : z \to u$, we have that $g \circ f : y \to u$ and therefore its image by the functor is the morphism

$F(g \circ f) : \text{Hom}_C(x, y) \to \text{Hom}_C(x, u)$

which verifies:

$F(g \circ f)(d) = g \circ f \circ d = g \circ (f \circ d) = F(g)(F(f)(d))$.

The identity axiom follows similarly.

name: Opposite Category
statement:
Let $C$ be a category. Its opposite category $C^{op}$:

$\bullet$ Has the same objects as $C$.
$\bullet$ For each pair of objects $x$ and $y$, it satisfies $\text{Hom}_{C^{op}}(x, y) := \text{Hom}_C(y, x)$. That is, we regard each morphism $f : y \to x$ in $C$ as a \
morphism\\: f^{op} : x \\to y$ in $C^{op}$.\n\n$\\bullet$ $f^{op} \\circ g^{op} = (g \\circ f)^{op}$.

name: Contravariant Hom-Functor
statement:
Fix a category $C$ and an object $x$. Using this data, we define a functor $F = \text{Hom}_C(-, x) : C^{op} \to \text{Set}$ as follows:

$\bullet$ Given $y \in \text{Ob}(C)$, we map it to $F(y) := \text{Hom}_C(y, x)$.
$\bullet$ Given objects $y, z \in \text{Ob}(C)$, we take a morphism $f : y \to z$ to $F(f) : \text{Hom}_C(z, x) \to \text{Hom}_C(y, x)$ by setting $F(f)(g) := f^*g = g \circ f$.

We say that $\text{Hom}_C(-, x)$ is the contravariant hom-functor associated to $x$.

name: Homotopy Invariance
statement:
Suppose that $f, g : B \to C$ are homotopic. Then:

$\bullet$ $f_*, g_* : [A, B] \to [A, C]$ are equal.
$\bullet$ $f^*, g^* : [C, A] \to [B, A]$ are equal.
proof:
The classes $[f]$ and $[g]$ are the same by assumption. It follows that

$f_* = [f]_* = \text{Hom}_{\text{hTop}}(A, -)([f]) = \text{Hom}_{\text{hTop}}(A, -)([g]) = [g]_* = g_* : [A, B] \to [A, C]$,

where the first and last equalities are simply the definition. The second statement is proven similarly.

name: Universal Property of Product
statement:
Let $C$ be a category, and let $a, b \in C$ be objects. A tuple $(p \in C, \pi_a : p \to a$ and $\pi_b : p \to b)$ is said to satisfy the universal property of the product if for any other tuple $(c \in C, f : c \to a, g : c \to b)$, there exists a unique morphism $(f, g) : c \to p$ such that the following diagram commutes:

$c$

$p$

$f$

$(f, g)$

$a$

$\pi_a$

$g$

$\pi_b$

$b$

I.e. $f = \pi_a \circ (f, g)$ and $g = \pi_b \circ (f, g)$.

name: Product Interaction with Homotopy
statement: Let $\\{M_i\\}^n_{i=1}$ be a finite collection of spaces. Fix an auxiliary space $A$. Then:\n\n$[A, \\prod_i M_i] \\simeq \\prod_i [A, M_i]$.
proof:
Using the definition of the product topology we see that

$f = (f_1, \cdot \cdot \cdot, f_n) : A \to \prod_i M_i$

is continuous if and only if each $f_i$ is continuous. It follows that $f \mapsto (f_1, \cdot \cdot \cdot, f_n)$ yields a bijection:

$\Phi : \text{Hom}_{\text{Top}}(A, \prod_i M_i) \simeq \prod_i \text{Hom}_{\text{Top}}(A, M_i)$.

We can then define a function

$\Psi : [A, \prod_i M_i] \to \prod_i [A, M_i]$

using the expression $[f] \mapsto ([f_1], \cdot \cdot \cdot, [f_n])$. We claim that it is well-defined and bijective. To show this, we reason as above and note that

$\text{Hom}_{\text{Top}}(A \times [0, 1], \prod_i M_i) \simeq \prod_i \text{Hom}_{\text{Top}}(A \times [0, 1], M_i)$,

meaning that the continuity of homotopies can be checked entry by entry. This implies that a homotopy of $[f]$ defines a homotopy of each entry, proving that $\Psi$ is well-defined. Surjectivity is clear, since $\Phi$ was surjective. For injectivity we observe that a collection of homotopies for the entries $[f_i]$ yields a homotopy of $[f]$.

name: Torus Non-contractibility
statement: The $n$-dimensional torus $T^n = (S^1)^n$ is not contractible.
proof: We use Proposition 3.26 to show $[S^1, T^n] \\simeq [S^1, S^1]^n \\simeq \\mathbb{Z}^n$, which is non-trivial.

name: Product Non-contractibility
statement: Let $\\{M_i\\}^n_{i=1}$ be a finite collection of non-empty spaces, with $M_1$ not contractible. Then $\\prod_i M_i$ is not contractible.
proof: According to Proposition 3.26 it holds that $[M_1, \\prod_i M_i] \\simeq \\prod_i [M_1, M_i]$. The cardinality of this product is at least two, since $[M_1, M_1]$ contains more than one element (since $M_1$ is not contractible), and each $[M_1, M_i]$ contains at least one element (since $M_i$ is non-empty).

name: Universal Property of Coproduct
statement:
Let $C$ be a category, and let $a, b \in C$ be objects. A tuple $(q \in C, \iota_a : a \to q$ and $\iota_b : b \to q)$ is said to satisfy the universal property of the coproduct if for any other tuple $(c \in C, f : a \to c, g : b \to c)$, there exists a unique morphism $f \amalg g : q \to c$ such that the following diagram commutes:

$c$

$q$

$f$

$f \amalg g$

$a$

$\iota_a$

$g$

$\iota_b$

$b$

Meaning that $f = (f \amalg g) \circ \iota_a$ and $g = (f \amalg g) \circ \iota_b$.

name: Coproduct Homotopy Classes
statement: Let $\\{M_i\\}^n_{i=1}$ be a finite collection of spaces. Fix a connected space $A$. Then: $[A, \\coprod_i M_i] \\simeq \\coprod_i [A, M_i]$.
proof: An element $[f]$ in $\\coprod_i[A, M_i]$ is an element in one of the $[A, M_i]$, for some $i$. We can see it as an element in $[A, \\coprod_i M_i]$ by composing $f$ with the inclusion $M_i \\to \\coprod_i M_i$. This defines a map $\\Psi : \\coprod_i [A, M_i] \\to [A, \\coprod_i M_i]$ that is injective. To prove surjectivity we consider $[g] \\in [A, \\coprod_i M_i]$ and we observe that $\\{A_i = g^{-1}(M_i)\\}$ is a partition of $A$ by open sets. By connectedness of $A$ it follows that all of them but one, say $A_i$, must be empty. It follows that $g$ takes values in $M_i$ and thus $[g]$ is in the image of $\\Psi$.

name: Product Homotopy Classes
statement: Let $\\{M_i\\}^n_{i=1}$ be a finite collection of spaces. Fix an auxiliary space $A$. Then: $[\\coprod_i M_i, A] \\simeq \\prod_i [M_i, A]$.
proof: Given a map $f : \\coprod_i M_i \\to A$ we can consider $f_i := f|_{M_i}$. Continuity of $f$ is equivalent to the continuity of each $f_i$ (for instance, by the Pasting Lemma 1.25). The function $f \\mapsto (f_1, \\cdots, f_n)$ is thus a bijection: $\\Phi : \\text{Hom}_{\\text{Top}}(\\coprod_i M_i, A) \\simeq \\prod_i \\text{Hom}_{\\text{Top}}(M_i, A)$. Similarly we define $\\Psi : [\\coprod_i M_i] \\to \\prod_i [M_i, A]$ using the expression $[f] \\mapsto ([f_1], \\cdots, [f_n])$. Homotopies of $f$ correspond to homotopies of each of the $[f_i]$, proving that $\\Psi$ is well-defined and bijective.

name: Maps of Pairs
statement: Let $A$ and $B$ be spaces with subspaces $A' \\subset A$ and $B' \\subset B$, respectively. A map of pairs $f : (A, A') \\to (B, B')$ is a continuous map $f : A \\to B$ satisfying $f(A') \\subset B'$.\n\nTwo maps $f, g : (A, A') \\to (B, B')$ are homotopic if there is a map of pairs $F : (A \\times [0, 1], A' \\times [0, 1]) \\to (B, B')$ with $F(-, 0) = f$ and $F(-, 1) = g$.

name: Homotopy Equivalence Relation
statement: Being homotopic is an equivalence relation for maps of pairs.

name: Pointed Space
statement: A pointed space is a pair $(X, x)$ consisting of a space and a point $x \\in X$. The point $x$ is often called the basepoint. A pointed map $f : (X, x) \\to (Y, y)$ is a continuous function $X \\to Y$ that preserves the basepoint, i.e. $f(x) = y$.

name: Point Map
statement: The only map from the point $({p}, {p})$ to a pointed space $(X, x)$ is the one sending $p$ to $x$.

name: Category of Pointed Spaces
statement:
The category of pointed spaces $\text{Top}_*$ is defined by:

$\bullet$ Its objects are pointed spaces.
$\bullet$ $\text{Hom}_{\text{Top}_*}((X, x), (Y, y))$ is the set of all pointed maps $(X, x) \to (Y, y)$.
$\bullet$ The composition is the usual composition of functions.
$\bullet$ The identity of $(X, x)$ is $\text{id}_X$, which is indeed pointed.

Observe that there is a forgetful functor $\text{Top}_* \to \text{Top}$ that sends $(X, x)$ to $X$.

name: Pointed Isomorphism
statement: A pointed map $f : (X, x) \\to (Y, y)$ is an isomorphism if and only if it is a homeomorphism.
proof: If $f$ is an isomorphism, it is sent to a homeomorphism in $\\text{Top}$ by the forgetful functor (because functors preserve isomorphisms). Conversely, if $f$ is a homeomorphism, it has a continuous inverse that is thus a bijection and thus pointed. This means that $f$ is invertible, so it is an isomorphism.

name: Simplest Pointed Space
statement: The empty space $\\emptyset$ is not an element of $\\text{Top}_*$, because it contains no points and thus no possible basepoint. Instead, the simplest pointed space is the point $({p}, p)$.

name: Pointed Isomorphism Rn
statement: Let $p, q \\in \\mathbb{R}^n$. We can consider the pointed map $f : (\\mathbb{R}^n, p) \\to (\\mathbb{R}^n, q)$ given by translating $f(x) = x + (q - p)$. This has $x \\mapsto x + (p - q)$ as pointed inverse. We deduce that $(\\mathbb{R}^n, p)$ and $(\\mathbb{R}^n, q)$ are isomorphic.

name: Pointed Isomorphism Sn
statement: Let $p, q \\in S^n$. We can then take $A \\in SO(n + 1)$ an orthogonal matrix satisfying $Ap = q$. Since $A$ defines a homeomorphism of $S^n$ with inverse $A^{-1}$, we deduce that $(S^n, p)$ and $(S^n, q)$ are isomorphic.

name: Pointed Homotopy
statement: Two pointed maps $f, g : (X, x) \\to (Y, y)$ are homotopic to each other if there is a pointed homotopy between them. That is, a map $F : X \\times [0, 1] \\to Y$ such that $f(a) = F(a, 0)$, $g(a) = F(a, 1)$, and $F(x, s) = y$ for all $s \\in [0, 1]$.\n\nPointed homotopy is an equivalence relation, so we can talk about the pointed homotopy class $[f]$ of a pointed map $f : (X, x) \\to (Y, y)$. The set of all pointed homotopy classes of maps is denoted by $[(X, x), (Y, y)]$.

name: Pointed Homotopy Category
statement: The pointed homotopy category $\\text{hTop}_*$ has pointed spaces as objects and pointed homotopy classes of maps as morphisms.

name: Pointed Homotopy Equivalence
statement: A pointed homotopy equivalence $f : (X, x) \\to (Y, y)$ is a map that has a pointed homotopy inverse $g : (Y, y) \\to (X, x)$, meaning that $g \\circ f$ is pointed homotopic to $\\text{id}_X$ and $f \\circ g$ is pointed homotopic to $\\text{id}_Y$. We then say that $f$ and $g$ are pointed homotopy inverses.

name: Pointed Contractibility
statement: Suppose a pointed space $(X, x)$ is pointed homotopy equivalent to the point $({p}, p)$. This means that the constant maps $c_x$ and $c_p$ are pointed homotopy inverses. This is the case if and only if $c_x \\circ c_p$ is pointed homotopic to $id_X$. I.e. if and only if $X$ deformation retracts to $x$.

name: Pointed Hom Functor
statement: Let $(A, a)$ be a pointed space. We write $[(A, a), -]$ for the covariant Hom functor $\\text{Hom}_{\\text{hTop}_*}((A, a), -) : \\text{hTop}_* \\to \\text{Set}$. One can similarly consider the contravariant version $[-, (A, a)]$.

name: Path Homotopy
statement: Given a space $X$ and points $x, y \\in X$ we can consider the set of paths $P := \\{\\gamma : [0, 1] \\to X | \\gamma(0) = x, \\gamma(1) = y\\}$. Two paths $\\gamma, \\nu \\in P$ are said to be homotopic relative to the endpoints if there is a homotopy $\\Gamma : [0, 1] \\times [0, 1] \\to X$ between $\\Gamma(t, 0) = \\gamma(t)$ and $\\Gamma(t, 1) = \\nu(t)$ that additionally satisfies $\\Gamma(0, s) = x$ and $\\Gamma(1, s) = y$ for all $s$. We write $\\pi_1(X, x, y)$ for the quotient of $P$ by the equivalence relation of homotopy relative to the endpoints. We write $\\Pi_1(X) := \\coprod_{x,y\\in X} \\pi_1(X, x, y)$ for the disjoint union of all these sets.
preconditions: map is a homotopy relative endpoints

name: Convex Path Homotopy
statement: Let $X \\subset \\mathbb{R}^n$ be convex. Then $\\pi_1(X, x, y) \\simeq \\{.\\}$ for all pairs of points $x, y \\in X$.
proof: Given $\\gamma, \\nu : [0, 1] \\to X$, both starting at $x$ and finishing at $y$, we have that the usual linear homotopy $F(t, s) := (1 - s)\\gamma(t) + s\\nu(t)$ preserves the endpoints $F(0, s) = (1 - s)\\gamma(0) + s\\nu(0) = (1 - s)x + sx = x$ and similarly $F(1, s) = y$, proving the statement.

name: Path Concatenation
statement: Fix points $x, y, z \\in X$ and paths $\\gamma, \\gamma', \\nu, \\nu' : [0, 1] \\to X$ such that $[\\gamma] = [\\gamma'] \\in \\pi_1(X, x, y)$ and $[\\nu] = [\\nu'] \\in \\pi_1(X, y, z)$. Then: $[\\nu \\bullet \\gamma] = [\\nu' \\bullet \\gamma'] \\in \\pi_1(X, x, z)$. Therefore, $([\\gamma], [\\nu]) \\mapsto [\\nu \\bullet \\gamma]$ is a well-defined function $\\Psi : \\pi_1(X, x, y) \\times \\pi_1(X, y, z) \\to \\pi_1(X, x, z)$.
proof:
Suppose that $G$ is a homotopy relative endpoints between $\gamma$ and $\gamma'$ and $N$ is a homotopy relative endpoints between $\nu$ and $\nu'$. Then:

$N \hat{\bullet}G(t, s) := \begin{cases} G(2t, s) & \text{for } t \in [0, 1/2] \\ N(2t - 1, s) & \text{for } t \in [1/2, 1] \end{cases}$

is a well-defined function, since $G(1, s) = y$ and $N(0, s) = y$. Furthermore, it satisfies

$(N \hat{\bullet}G)(t, 0) = N(-, 0) \bullet G(-, 0) = \nu \bullet \gamma$

and

$(N \hat{\bullet}G)(t, 1) = N(-, 1) \bullet G(-, 1) = \nu' \bullet \gamma'$.

To prove that it is continuous we apply the Pasting Lemma, noting that it is continuous in each of the pieces $[0, 1/2] \times [0, 1]$ and $[1/2, 1] \times [0, 1]$, thanks to the continuity of $G$ and $N$.

name: Associativity of Paths
statement: Fix points $x, y, z, u \\in X$ and paths $\\gamma, \\nu, \\beta : [0, 1] \\to X$ with $[\\gamma] \\in \\pi_1(X, x, y)$, $[\\nu] \\in \\pi_1(X, y, z)$, and $[\\beta] \\in \\pi_1(X, z, u)$. Then: $[\\beta \\bullet (\\nu \\bullet \\gamma)] = [(\\beta \\bullet \\nu) \\bullet \\gamma]$.
proof:
Let us observe first that $\beta \bullet (\nu \bullet \gamma)$ and $(\beta \bullet \nu) \bullet \gamma$ are not the same path a priori. Indeed:

$((\beta \bullet \nu) \bullet \gamma)(t) := \begin{cases} \gamma(2t) & \text{for } t \in [0, 1/2] \\ \nu(4t - 2) & \text{for } t \in [1/2, 3/4] \\ \beta(4t - 3) & \text{for } t \in [3/4, 1] \end{cases}$

meaning that $\nu$ and $\beta$ are run at double the speed compared to $\gamma$. In comparison:

$(\beta \bullet (\nu \bullet \gamma))(t) := \begin{cases} \gamma(4t) & \text{for } t \in [0, 1/4] \\ \nu(4t - 1) & \text{for } t \in [1/4, 1/2] \\ \beta(2t - 1) & \text{for } t \in [1/2, 1] \end{cases}$

which shows that we are basically performing the same path, just at a different pace.

It follows that we have to homotope between the two \
speeds\\:
We claim that there exists an increasing homeomorphism $\chi : [0, 1] \to [0, 1]$ such that:

$((\beta \bullet \nu) \bullet \gamma)(t) = (\beta \bullet (\nu \bullet \gamma))(\chi(t))$.

Indeed:

$\chi(t) := \begin{cases} t/2 & \text{for } t \in [0, 1/2] \\ t - 1/4 & \text{for } t \in [1/2, 3/4] \\ 2t - 1 & \text{for } t \in [3/4, 1] \end{cases}$

does the job. To conclude the proof it is enough to show that the identity $\text{id}_{[0,1]}$ is homotopic to $\chi$, relative endpoints. Indeed, given such a homotopy $\chi_s : [0, 1] \to [0, 1]$, it holds that $\beta \bullet (\nu \bullet \gamma)(\chi_s(t))$ is a homotopy starting at $\beta \bullet (\nu \bullet \gamma)$ and finishing at $(\beta \bullet \nu) \bullet \gamma$. The existence of such a homotopy follows from Lemma 4.18, since the interval is convex.

name: Identity Paths
statement: Fix points $x, y, z \\in X$. Then, for all paths $[\\gamma] \\in \\pi_1(X, x, y)$ and $[\\nu] \\in \\pi_1(X, z, x)$: $[\\gamma \\bullet c_x] = [\\gamma]$, $[c_x \\bullet \\nu] = [\\nu] \\in \\pi_1(X, z, x)$.
proof:
We can write $\gamma \bullet c_x(t) = \gamma(\alpha(t))$, where

$\alpha(t) := \begin{cases} 0 & \text{for } t \in [0, 1/2] \\ 2t - 1 & \text{for } t \in [1/2, 1] \end{cases}$,

as shown in Figure 4.3. The function $\alpha : [0, 1] \to [0, 1]$ begins at 0 and ends at 1, so it is homotopic relative endpoints to $\text{id}_{[0,1]}$, according to Lemma 4.18. If we write $(\alpha_s)_{s\in[0,1]}$ for such a homotopy, we have that $\gamma \circ \alpha_s$ homotopes between $\gamma \bullet c_x$ and $\gamma$.

name: Inverse Paths
statement: Fix points $x, y \\in X$ and a path $\\gamma : [0, 1] \\to X$ such that $[\\gamma] \\in \\pi_1(X, x, y)$. Then: $[\\bar{\\gamma} \\bullet \\gamma] = [c_x] \\in \\pi_1(X, x, x)$ and $[\\gamma \\bullet \\bar{\\gamma}] = [c_y] \\in \\pi_1(X, y, y)$.
proof:
Observe that $\bar{\gamma} \bullet \gamma(t) = \gamma(\rho(t))$, where

$\rho(t) := \begin{cases} 2t & \text{for } t \in [0, 1/2] \\ 2 - 2t & \text{for } t \in [1/2, 1] \end{cases}$

is shown in Figure 4.4. Observe that $\rho : [0, 1] \to [0, 1]$ begins and ends at 0, so it is homotopic relative endpoints to the constant path $c_0$, according to Lemma 4.18. If we let $(\rho_s)_{s\in[0,1]}$ be such a homotopy, we have that $(\gamma \circ \rho_s)_{s\in[0,1]}$ homotopes between $\bar{\gamma} \bullet \gamma$ and the constant path $c_x$, as claimed. The second item follows from the first by swapping $\gamma$ and $\bar{\gamma}$.

name: Fundamental Groupoid
statement:
The fundamental groupoid of a space $X$ is the category $\Pi_1(X)$ such that:

• Its class of objects is $X$, seen as a set.
• Given points $x, y \in X$, the morphisms between them are the set $\pi_1(X, x, y)$ (Definition 4.17).
• The composition is given by concatenation of homotopy classes (Lemma 4.19).
• The identity at $x$ is the class of the constant path $[c_x]$.
• Each $[\gamma] \in \pi_1(X, x, y)$ has an inverse $[\bar{\gamma}] \in \pi_1(X, y, x)$ given by reversing.
proof: The composition is well-defined by Lemma 4.19, it is associative by Lemma 4.20, it has the claimed identities by Lemma 4.21, and has inverses given by the class of the reversal by Lemma 4.22.
preconditions: map is a homotopy relative endpoints

name: Fundamental Group
statement: The fundamental group of a space $X$ at a point $x \\in X$ is the group $\\pi_1(X, x) := \\pi_1(X, x, x)$, endowed with the composition coming from $\\Pi_1(X)$.

name: Groupoid
statement: A groupoid $G$ is a category in which all morphisms are isomorphisms.

name: Isomorphic Objects
statement: Let $G$ be a groupoid. Let $x, y \\in \\text{Ob}(G)$ be objects. Then, either $\\text{Hom}_G(x, y)$ is empty or $x$ and $y$ are isomorphic.
proof: If a morphism $f : x \\to y$ between the two exists, it is an isomorphism.

name: Group as Groupoid
statement: If $G$ is a group and we see it as a category, we readily see that it is a groupoid, since all morphisms are invertible. We can emphasise that we see it as a groupoid by writing $G \\Rightarrow \\{p\\}$. I.e. there is a single object, denoted by $p$, and thus $s(g) = t(g) = p$ for all elements $g \\in G$. The group $G$ is thus the isotropy of $p$.

name: Pair Groupoid
statement: If $X$ is a set, we can consider its pair groupoid, which we denote by $X \\times X \\Rightarrow X$. This means that the objects are given by $X$ and the morphisms by $X \\times X$. Each element $(x, y) \\in X \\times X$ is the unique morphism from $x$ to $y$. It follows that $(y, z) \\circ (x, y) = (x, z)$. The identities are the elements of the form $(x, x)$. Similarly, the inverse of $(x, y)$ is $(y, x)$.

name: Fundamental Groupoid
statement: Let $X$ be a space. Then, $\\Pi_1(X) \\Rightarrow X$ is a groupoid.
proof: This was proven above.

name: Isotropy Group
statement: Let $G \\Rightarrow B$ be a groupoid and let $x \\in B$ be an object. Then, the isotropy $G_x$ is a group.
proof: (1) All the morphisms in $G_x$ have $x$ as source and target, so all of them can be composed with one another. It follows that there is a well-defined operation. (2) The identity $\\text{id}_x$ belongs to $G_x$. (3) Since $G$ is a groupoid, every morphism is invertible, so $G_x$ contains inverses for all the elements. (4) The composition in $G_x$ is associative, since it is induced from the composition in $G$, which is itself associative.

name: Groupoid Connectivity
statement:
Let $G \Rightarrow B$ be a groupoid.

$\bullet$ Two objects $x, y \in B$ are said to be connected if $G_{x,y} \neq \emptyset$.
$\bullet$ We write $\pi_0(G)$ for the set of equivalence classes of $B$ with respect to the connectedness equivalence relation.
$\bullet$ $G$ is connected if all its elements are connected.

name: Connected Isomorphism
statement: All the objects in a connected groupoid are isomorphic to one another.
proof: Since a groupoid always has inverses, we deduce that if two objects are connected, they are isomorphic.

name: Groupoid Components
statement:
Let $G \Rightarrow B$ be a groupoid. Given an equivalence class $\alpha \in \pi_0(G)$, we can consider the groupoid $G_\alpha \Rightarrow B_\alpha$ defined as:

$\bullet$ $B_\alpha = \{x \in B \mid [x] = \alpha\}$.
$\bullet$ $\text{Hom}_{G_\alpha}(x, y) = \text{Hom}_G(x, y)$ for every $x, y \in B_\alpha$.

$G_\alpha \Rightarrow B_\alpha$ is said to be a component of $G \Rightarrow B$.
That is, we are effectively partitioning

$G \Rightarrow B = \coprod_{\alpha\in\pi_0(G)} G_\alpha \Rightarrow B_\alpha$

into (disjoint) groupoids, all of which are connected.

name: Path-component Correspondence
statement:
Let $X$ be a space. Then:

$\bullet$ $\pi_0(\Pi_1(X)) \simeq \pi_0(X)$.
$\bullet$ In particular, $X$ is path-connected if and only if $\Pi_1(X) \Rightarrow X$ is connected.
$\bullet$ The partition $X = \coprod_i X_i$ into path-components corresponds to the partition $\Pi_1(X) = \coprod_i \Pi_1(X_i)$ into components.
proof: The bijection claimed in the first item is given by the function $f : \\pi_0(X) \\to \\pi_0(\\Pi_1(X))$ that takes $[x] \\in \\pi_0(X)$ to $[x] \\in \\pi_0(\\Pi_1(X))$. We see that this is well-defined, since the equivalence class on the left means that $[x] = [y] \\in \\pi_0(X)$ if a path exists between the two, which is equivalent to $\\pi_1(X, x, y) \\neq \\emptyset$, which defines the equivalence class on the right. Surjectivity is clear, since $X$ is the base of the groupoid. Injectivity follows from the argument we gave for well-defined. The other two items follow immediately.

name: Conjugation Function
statement:
The conjugation of $f \in G_{y,z}$ at $z$ is the function:

$\beta_f : G_{z,z} \to G_{y,y}$

given by $\beta_f(g) = (f^{-1})_* \circ f^*(g) = f^{-1} \circ g \circ f$.

name: Conjugation Properties
statement:
Let $G \Rightarrow B$ be a groupoid. Let $f \in G_{y,z}$. Then:

$\bullet$ $f_*$ and $f^*$ are bijections.
$\bullet$ $\beta_f$ is a group isomorphism.
proof:
First observe that $\beta_f : G_{z,z} \to G_{y,y}$ is indeed a function between isotropy groups, so it makes sense for us to study whether it is a group isomorphism. Note furthermore, that $G_{x,y}$ and $G_{x,z}$ are simply sets if $x \neq y, z$, so $f_*$ and $f^*$ can at most be bijections.

To prove the first claim observe that $f$ has an inverse $f^{-1}$, since $G$ is a groupoid, and $f_*$ and $f^{-1}_*$ are inverses, meaning that both are bijections. The same reasoning applies to the pullback.

For the second claim we readily see from the formula $\beta_f = (f^{-1})_* \circ f^*$ that $\beta_f$ is a bijection. It remains to prove that it is a group homomorphism. We see that it preserves the identity

$\beta_f(\text{id}_z) = f^{-1} \circ \text{id}_z \circ f = f^{-1} \circ f = \text{id}_y$,

and furthermore it preserves the composition:

$\beta_f(h \circ g) = f^{-1} \circ h \circ g \circ f = (f^{-1} \circ h \circ f) \circ (f^{-1} \circ g \circ f) = \beta_f(h) \circ \beta_f(g)$.

name: Trivial Conjugation
statement: Let $G$ be the groupoid associated to the group $G$. Then the conjugation $\\beta_f : G \\to G$ given by $f \\in G$ is trivial if and only if $f$ commutes with every $g \\in G$.
proof: We see that $\\beta_f(g) = f^{-1}gf$ is equal to $g$ if and only if $gf = fg$, which was the claim.

name: Abelian Characterization
statement: A group $G$ is abelian if and only if all conjugations $\\beta_f$ are trivial.

name: Non-trivial Conjugations
statement: Suppose $G$ is the groupoid defined by the group general linear group $GL(n)$ (i.e. the group of invertible $n \\times n$ matrices). If $n > 1$, $GL(n)$ is not abelian, since not all matrices commute. This implies that the there are non-trivial conjugations in $G$.

name: Category of Small Categories
statement:
The category $Cat$ of small categories is given by:

$\bullet$ Its objects are all the small categories.
$\bullet$ Given categories $C$ and $D$ in $Ob(Cat)$, its class of morphisms $Hom_{Cat}(C, D)$ consists of all the functors $F : C \to D$.

Functors can be composed and the identity functors (mapping each object and morphism to itself) play then the role of the identities.

name: Functor Isomorphism Criterion
statement: A functor $F : C \\to D$ is an isomorphism if and only if it is a bijection both between objects and between morphisms.
proof: $F$ is an isomorphism if and only if there is an inverse functor $G : D \\to C$, meaning that $G \\circ F = id_C$ and $F \\circ G = id_D$. This necessarily implies that $F$ and $G$ induce bijections between objects and between morphisms. This is seen to be sufficient as well, since the set-theoretical inverse of a functor inducing bijections between objects and between morphisms must also preserve identities and compositions, so it is also a functor.

name: Category of Groupoids
statement:
The category $Grpoid$ is the subcategory of $Cat$ such that:

$\bullet$ It objects are all the small groupoids.
$\bullet$ $Hom_{Grpoid}(C, D) = Hom_{Cat}(C, D)$ for any two groupoids $C$ and $D$.

name: Fundamental Groupoid Pushforward
statement:
Let $f : X \to Y$ be a map of spaces. Its pushforward (at the level of fundamental groupoids) is the functor

$f_* : \Pi_1(X) \to \Pi_1(Y )$

defined by:

$\bullet$ $f_*(x) = f(x) \in Y$ for every object $x \in Ob(\Pi_1(X)) = X$.
$\bullet$ $f_*([\gamma]) = [f \circ \gamma] \in \pi_1(Y, f(x), f(y))$ for every morphism $\gamma \in \pi_1(X, x, y)$ and every $x, y \in X$.

name: Pushforward Well-Defined
statement: The pushforward is well-defined.
proof: One needs to check that the definition $f_*([\\gamma]) = [f \\circ \\gamma]$ does not depend on the choice of representative $\\gamma$. This follows from the fact that any homotopy $\\gamma_t$ of $\\gamma$ relative endpoints can be pushed forward using $f$ to produce a homotopy $f \\circ \\gamma_t$ of $f \\circ \\gamma$ relative endpoints. We leave the details to the reader.

name: Fundamental Groupoid Functor
statement:
We write $\Pi_1 : \text{Top} \to \text{Grpoid}$ for the functor that:

$\bullet$ Sends a space $X$ to its fundamental groupoid $\Pi_1(X)$.
$\bullet$ Sends a morphism $f : X \to Y$ to its pushforward $f_* : \Pi_1(X) \to \Pi_1(Y)$.
proof: We readily see that $(\\text{id}_X)_* = \\text{id}_{\\Pi_1(X)}$, so identities are preserved. Similarly, $g_* \\circ f_* = (g \\circ f)_*$ so compositions are preserved. This shows that $\\Pi_1$ is indeed a functor. Details are left to the reader.

name: Homeomorphism Isomorphism
statement: If $X$ and $Y$ are homeomorphic, their fundamental groupoids $\\Pi_1(X)$ and $\\Pi_1(Y)$ are isomorphic.
proof: This is immediate from the fact that functors send isomorphisms to isomorphisms.

name: Fundamental Group Pushforward
statement:
Let $f : (X, x) \to (Y, y)$ be a pointed map. Its pushforward (at the level of fundamental groups) is the group homomorphism

$f_* : \pi_1(X, x) \to \pi_1(Y, y)$

defined by $f_*([\gamma]) = [f \circ \gamma]$.
proof: This is well-defined (i.e. does not depend on the choice of representative $\\gamma$) because the same statement was true for the pushforward of fundamental groupoids.

name: Fundamental Group Functor
statement:
We write $\pi_1 : \text{Top}_* \to \text{Grp}$ for the functor that:

$\bullet$ Sends a pointed space $(X, x)$ to its fundamental group $\pi_1(X, x)$.
$\bullet$ Sends a pointed map $f : (X, x) \to (Y, y)$ to its pushforward $f_* : \pi_1(X, x) \to \pi_1(Y, y)$.
proof: That this is a functor (i.e. preserves compositions and identities) follows once again from the fact that $\\pi_1(X, x)$ sits inside $\\Pi_1(X)$ as the isotropy at $x$.

name: Retract Pushforward
statement: Let $A \\subset B$ be a retract; denote the retraction by $r$ and the inclusion by $i$. Fix a point $a \\in A$. Then $r_* : \\pi_1(B, a) \\to \\pi_1(A, a)$ is surjective and $i_*$ is its inverse.
proof: In $\\text{Top}_*$, the map $r$ is a left-inverse of $i$. Since $\\pi_1$ is a functor, it preserves invertibility (Lemma 1.16), so $r_* = \\pi_1(r)$ is a left-inverse in $\\text{Grp}$ of $i_* = \\pi_1(i)$. It follows that the former is surjective and the latter is injective.

name: Pointed Homotopy Invariance
statement: Suppose that $f, g : (X, x) \\to (Y, y)$ are pointed homotopic. Then $f_* = g_*$.
proof: A pointed homotopy $F$ from $f$ to $g$ produces a pointed homotopy $F \\circ \\gamma$ of $\\gamma$.

name: Functor to Grp
statement: We can regard $\\pi_1$ as a functor $\\text{hTop}_* \\to \\text{Grp}$.
proof: The functor takes a morphism $[f]$ in $\\text{hTop}_*$ to $f_*$, as defined in Definition 5.20. That this does not depend on the representative $f$ was precisely the content of the previous lemma. That this defines a functor is immediate from the fact that we earlier defined $\\pi_1$ as a functor with domain $\\text{Top}$.

name: Homotopy Equivalence Invariance
statement: If $(X, x)$ and $(Y, y)$ are pointed homotopy equivalent, their fundamental groups $\\pi_1(X, x)$ and $\\pi_1(Y, y)$ are isomorphic.

name: Change of Basepoint
statement:
Let $X$ be a space. Let $x, y, z, w \in X$ be points in the same path-component. Then:

$\bullet$ $\pi_1(X, x) \simeq \pi_1(X, y)$ as groups.
$\bullet$ $\pi_1(X, x, y) \simeq \pi_1(X, z, w)$ as sets.
proof:
Since $x$ and $y$ are in the same path-component there is a path $\gamma$ from one to the other. I.e. $[\gamma] \in \pi_1(X, x, y)$. It follows that

$\beta_{[\gamma]} : \pi_1(X, y) \to \pi_1(X, x)$

is a group isomorphism according to Lemma 5.6. This proves the first claim. The second one is proven similarly using the pullback and the pushforward.

name: Path Homotopy Formula
statement:
Let $F : [0, 1]^2 \to X$ be a homotopy of paths (not relative endpoints). Denote $\gamma_s = F(-, s)$ for the path at time $s$. Write as well $\alpha_s(t) = F(0, ts)$ and $\tau_s(t) = F(1, ts)$.

Then, $[\gamma_s] \in \pi_1(X, \gamma_s(0), \gamma_s(1))$ relates to $[\gamma_0] \in \pi_1(X, \gamma_0(0), \gamma_0(1))$ by the formula:

$[\gamma_0] = [\tau_s] \bullet [\gamma_s] \bullet [\alpha_s]$.
proof:
We must exhibit a homotopy relative endpoints between $\gamma_0$ and $\tau_s \bullet (\gamma_s \bullet \alpha_s)$. The idea is shown in Figure 6.2: it amounts to performing a homotopy within $[0, 1]^2$.

Consider the paths

$\beta_0, \beta_1 : [0, 1] \to [0, 1]^2$

given by $\beta_0(t) = (t, 0)$ and

$\beta_1 = (t \mapsto (1, st)) \bullet ((t \mapsto (t, s)) \bullet (t \mapsto (0, st)))$.

These paths are defined so that $\gamma_0 = F \circ \beta_0$ and $\tau_s \bullet (\gamma_s \bullet \alpha_s) = F \circ \beta_1$. Furthermore, both paths define classes in $\pi_1([0, 1]^2, (0, 0), (1, 0))$, which consists of a single element, according to Lemma 4.18. This implies that there is a homotopy relative endpoints $G : [0, 1]^2 \to [0, 1]^2$ with $G(-, 0) = \beta_0$ and $G(-, 1) = \beta_1$. The argument concludes by setting $F \circ G$ as the desired homotopy relative endpoints.

name: Loop Homotopy Formula
statement:
Let $F : S^1 \times [0, 1] \to X$ be a homotopy of loops. Denote $\gamma_s = F(-, s)$ for the loop at time $s$. Write $\alpha_s(t) = F(1, ts)$.

Then, $[\gamma_s] \in \pi_1(X, \gamma_s(0))$ relates to $[\gamma_0] \in \pi_1(X, \gamma_0(0))$ by the formula:

$[\gamma_0] = [\alpha_s] \bullet [\gamma_s] \bullet [\overline{\alpha_s}]$.
proof: This is a direct application of Theorem 6.3 to the special case of loops. Since we're working with loops, the endpoints coincide, and the formula simplifies to the conjugation by $[\\alpha_s]$.

name: Map Homotopy Formula
statement: Let $F : X \\times [0, 1] \\to Y$ be a homotopy. Denote $f_s : X \\to Y$ for the map $f_s := F(-, s)$. Fix a point $x \\in X$ and denote $\\alpha_s : [0, 1] \\to X$ for the path $\\alpha_s(t) := F(x, st)$. Then:\n\n$(f_0)_* = \\beta_{[\\alpha_s]} \\circ (f_s)_* : \\pi_1(X, x) \\to \\pi_1(Y, f_0(x))$.
proof:
Each map $f_s$ defines its own pushforward $(f_s)_* : \pi_1(X, x) \to \pi_1(Y, f_s(x))$. Since the basepoint $f_s(x)$ in $Y$ moves with $s$, the pushforwards cannot possibly be the same for all $s$. However, we will prove that they are related by conjugation.

Given any class of loop $[\gamma] \in \pi_1(X, x)$ we can take a representative $\gamma$ and consider the homotopy of loops $G : S^1 \times [0, 1] \to Y$ defined by $G := F \circ \gamma$. Applying Corollary 6.4 we obtain:

$(f_0)_*([\gamma]) = [f_0 \circ \gamma] = [\alpha_s] \bullet [f_s \circ \gamma] \bullet [\overline{\alpha_s}] = \beta_{[\alpha_s]} \circ (f_s)_*([\gamma])$,

as claimed.

name: Homotopy Equivalence Isomorphism
statement: Let $f : X \\to Y$ be a homotopy equivalence. Then $f_* : \\pi_1(X, x) \\to \\pi_1(Y, f(x))$ is an isomorphism for all $x \\in X$.
proof:
In the upcoming proof it is important that we keep track of the domains and codomains of the pushforwards we compute.

Let $g : Y \to X$ be a homotopy inverse of $f$. Since $g \circ f$ is homotopic to $\text{id}_X$ we deduce (Theorem 6.5) that

$g_* \circ f_* = (g \circ f)_* : \pi_1(X, x) \to \pi_1(X, g(f(x)))$

and $(\text{id}_X)_* = \text{id}_{\pi_1(X,x)}$ are conjugate to each other. In particular, since conjugation is an isomorphism, we deduce that $g_* \circ f_*$ is an isomorphism. It follows that $g_* : \pi_1(Y, f(x)) \to \pi_1(X, g(f(x)))$ is surjective.

We similarly observe that

$f_* \circ g_* = (f \circ g)_* : \pi_1(Y, f(x)) \to \pi_1(X, f(g(f(x))))$

so $g_* : \pi_1(Y, f(x)) \to \pi_1(X, g(f(x)))$ is injective. It follows that it is bijective. In turn, it follows that $f_* : \pi_1(X, x) \to \pi_1(Y, f(x))$ had to be a bijection as well.

name: Product in Grpoid
statement: Let $G \\Rightarrow B$ and $G' \\Rightarrow B'$ be groupoids. Then their product in Grpoid is their product as sets, both at the level of objects and morphisms: $G \\times G' \\Rightarrow B \\times B'$. Concretely, a morphism in $G \\times G'$ from $(a, a') \\in B \\times B'$ to $(b, b')$ is a pair $(f : a \\to b, f' : a' \\to b')$. Composition is performed componentwise.
proof:
Write $\pi$ and $\pi'$ for the functors projecting $G \times G'$ to $G$ and $G'$, respectively. Consider some other groupoid $H \Rightarrow C$ and a pair of functors $F : H \to G$ and $F' : H \to G'$. We can then define $(F, F') : H \to G \times G'$ to be the (usual, set-theoretical) product map at the level of objects and morphisms. Due to the universal property of the product in Set, $(F, F')$ is the unique function that factorises $F$ and $F'$, meaning $\pi \circ (F, F') = F$ and $\pi' \circ (F, F') = F'$. We just need to check that it is a functor.

First, note that $(F, F')$ defines a function at the object level $C \to B \times B'$ and another at the morphism level. We must show these are compatible in the sense that each morphism $h : x \to y$ in $H$ must be taken to a morphism $(F, F')(f)$ with source $(F, F')(x)$ and target $(F, F')(y)$. This is readily checked, since $(F, F')(f) = (F(f), F'(f))$ has source $(F(x), F'(x)) = (F, F')(x)$ and target $(F(y), F'(y)) = (F, F')(y)$.

Let $h$ and $j$ be composable morphisms in $H$. We see that

$(F, F')(h \circ j) = (F(h \circ j), F'(h \circ j)) = (F(h) \circ F(j), F'(h) \circ F'(j)) = (F, F')(h) \circ (F, F')(j)$

so $(F, F')$ preserves compositions. Similarly, it preserves identities, so it is a functor.

name: Groupoid Product Preservation
statement: Let $\\{X_i\\}^n_{i=1}$ be a finite collection of spaces. Then: $\\Pi_1(\\prod_i X_i) \\simeq \\prod_i \\Pi_1(X_i)$.
proof: This is a consequence of the properties of the product topology, as in the proof of Proposition 3.26; details are left to the reader.

name: Pointed Product Property
statement: Let $(X, x)$ and $(Y, y)$ be pointed spaces. Then $(X \\times Y, (x, y))$ satisfies the universal property of the product in $\\text{Top}_*$.
proof: $X \\times Y$ is the usual product in Top, so every pair of maps $f : Z \\to X$ and $g : Z \\to Y$ factors through uniquely via the map $(f, g) : Z \\to X \\times Y$. It remains to show that this unique factorising map is in fact a morphism in $\\text{Top}_*$, i.e. it is pointed. If $f$ and $g$ are pointed, for a choice of basepoint $z \\in Z$, $x \\in X$, and $y \\in Y$, we readily see that $(f, g)$ is also pointed once we set $(x, y)$ to be the basepoint in $X \\times Y$.

name: Fundamental Group Product
statement: Let $\\{(X_i, x_i)\\}^n_{i=1}$ be a finite collection of spaces. Then: $\\pi_1(\\prod_i (X_i, x_i)) \\simeq \\prod_i \\pi_1(X_i, x_i)$.
proof: This is an immediate corollary of Proposition 6.8.

name: Torus Fundamental Group
statement:
Let $(T^n, p) = \prod^n_{i=1}(S^1, 1)$ be the pointed $n$-dimensional torus. Then:

$\bullet$ $\pi_1(T^n, p) \simeq Z^n$, as groups.

$\bullet$ $T^n$ and $T^m$ are homotopy equivalent if and only if $n = m$.
proof: Note that $(T^n, p)$ and $(T^n, q)$ are homeomorphic for any two choices of basepoint $p$ and $q$. This follows as in Example 4.9: the translations are homeomorphisms and allow us to move $p$ to $q$. This implies that $\\pi_1(T^n, p) \\simeq \\pi_1(T^n, q)$, so we can compute the fundamental group at any point of the torus. The first statement then follows from the fact $\\pi_1(S^1, 1) \\simeq Z$ and Corollary 6.10, by considering the basepoint $(1, 1, \\ldots, 1)$.\n\nThe second statement follows from the first. Homotopy equivalent spaces have isomorphic fundamental groups (Corollary 6.6) and $Z^n$ and $Z^m$ are not isomorphic if $n \\neq m$ (Lemma 6.12 below).

name: Non-isomorphic Zn
statement: The additive groups $\\mathbb{Z}^n$ and $\\mathbb{Z}^m$ are not isomorphic if $n \\neq m$.
proof: This proof is deferred to Lemma 8.4 in the next chapter where groups are examined more closely.

name: Fundamental Group Circle
statement: $\\pi_1(S^1, 1) \\cong \\mathbb{Z}$, as groups.
proof: The proof is deferred to Section 10.3.

name: Simply-connected Space
statement:
Let $X$ be a space. A space is simply-connected if the following conditions hold:

$\bullet$ $X$ is path-connected.
$\bullet$ $\pi_1(X, x) = \{[c_x]\}$ for some $x \in X$.

name: Simply-connected Equivalences
statement:
The following are equivalent for a non-empty space $X$:

a. $X$ is simply-connected.
b. $X$ is path-connected and $\pi_1(X, x) = \{[c_x]\}$ for all $x \in X$.
c. $\pi_1(X, x, y) \cong \{.\}$ for all $x, y \in X$.
d. $\Pi_1(X)$ is isomorphic to the pair groupoid $X \times X \Rightarrow X$.
e. $[S^1, X] \cong \{.\}$.
proof:
(a) implies (b). Indeed, all fundamental groups in a component are isomorphic to one another, so triviality of one of them implies triviality of all. The reverse implication is obvious.

(a) implies (c). Due to path-connectedness, all morphism sets in $\Pi_1(X)$ are isomorphic and thus consist of a single element. For the converse, note that all morphism sets in $\Pi_1(X)$ being non-empty implies that $X$ is path-connected. Morphism sets consisting of a single element gives in particular that the fundamental group at each basepoint is trivial.

(c) implies (d). Indeed, assumption (c) says that all morphism sets in $\Pi_1(X)$ consist of a single element. The unique morphism $[\gamma] \in \pi_1(X, x, y)$ is then identified with the morphism $(x, y)$ in $X \times Y$. This is readily seen to be a bijection $\Pi_1(X) \to X \times X$ which, by uniqueness of morphism sets, automatically preserves composition and inverses and is thus a functor.

(b) implies (e). Take a class $[\gamma] \in [S^1, X]$ and note that $\gamma$ also represents a class in $\pi_1(X, \gamma(1))$. Item (b) implies that this class is trivial, meaning that $\gamma$ is nullhomotopic using a homotopy relative endpoints. In particular, it is nullhomotopic without fixing endpoints.

(e) implies (a). Recall that there is an injective map $\pi_0(X) \to [S^1, X]$ sending $[x]$ to the class of the constant map $[c_x]$. Item (e) then implies $\pi_0(X) \cong \{.\}$, meaning that $X$ is path-connected. Consider now a class $[\gamma] \in \pi_1(X, x)$ and regard it as a class in $[S^1, X]$. I.e. we take the loop $\gamma : S^1 \to X$, which is based at $x \in X$, and now we allow homotopies $F : S^1 \times [0, 1] \to X$ which are not relative endpoints (i.e. $F(0, s)$ may not be $x$). Consider the path $\alpha : [0, 1] \to X$ given by $\alpha(t) = F(1, t)$.

The assumption $[S^1, X] \cong \{.\}$ says that there is a homotopy $F$ between $\gamma$ and a constant loop $c_z$. Using the change of basepoint formula (Theorem 6.3) we then deduce

$[\gamma] = [\alpha] \bullet [c_z] \bullet [\alpha] = [\alpha] \bullet [\alpha] = [c_x]$.

Since this is true for all homotopy classes in $\pi_1(X, x)$, simply-connectedness follows.

name: Contractible Simply-connected
statement: A contractible space $X$ is simply-connected.
proof: According to Lemma 3.1, $[S^1, X] = \\{.\\}$, which implies the result thanks to the criteria in Lemma 6.15.

name: Equivalence of Categories
statement:
An equivalence of categories is a functor $F : C \to D$ that satisfies:

• Essential surjectivity: For every object $d \in D$ there is $c \in C$ such that $d$ is isomorphic to $F(c)$.

• Fullness and faithfulness: $F : \text{Hom}_C(c, c') \to \text{Hom}_D(F(c), F(c'))$ is a bijection for all objects $c, c' \in C$.
preconditions: map is an equivalence of categories

name: Skeleton of Category
statement:
Let $C$ be a category. A skeleton of $C$ is a subcategory $D$ satisfying:

• The inclusion $D \to C$ is an equivalence.
• If $a$ and $b$ are isomorphic objects in $D$, then $a = b$.

That is, for each isomorphism class of objects in $C$, $D$ contains exactly one representative. By taking $D$, we have removed redundancies in $C$.

name: Vector Space Skeleton
statement: Let $\\text{Vect}^{\\text{fin}}_R$ be the category of finite dimensional vector spaces over $R$, with linear maps as morphisms. Then the subcategory whose objects are $\\{R^n\\}_n$ and whose morphisms are all linear maps is a skeleton. This follows from the fact that every finite dimensional vector space is isomorphic to $R^n$, for some $n$.

name: Skeleton Existence
statement: Every category $C$ has a skeleton.
proof: The proof uses the axiom of choice. The class of objects $\\text{Ob}(C)$ can be partitioned into the equivalence classes given by isomorphism of objects. The axiom of choice tells us that we can select one object per equivalence class. The collection of these will be $\\text{Ob}(D)$.
