name: Surfaces Monoid Structure
statement: Consider the set $M$ consisting of all compact, path-connected surfaces up to homeomorphism. Then, $(M, \\#)$ is a commutative monoid with identity.
proof: The sphere is the identity, according to Corollary 15.21. Commutativity follows from the fact that the presentations $P \\# Q$ and $Q \\# P$ are described by the same word, due to cyclicity.

name: Surfaces Monoid Generators
statement:
$(M, \#)$ is generated by $\mathbb{RP}^2$ and $T^2$. Moreover:

$\bullet$ $N_g$ is the connected sum of $g$ copies of $\mathbb{RP}^2$.
$\bullet$ $\Sigma_g$ is the connected sum of $g$ copies of $T^2$.
proof: The two items follow from the description of the standard presentations and imply the claim about being generators.

name: Surfaces Monoid Relations
statement: $(M, \\#)$ is generated by $\\mathbb{RP}^2$ and $T^2$, with relation\n\n$\\mathbb{RP}^2 \\# T^2 \\simeq \\mathbb{RP}^2 \\# \\mathbb{RP}^2 \\# \\mathbb{RP}^2$.
proof: The claimed relation is the identity $\\Sigma_1 \\# N_1 \\simeq N_3$, which was established in Corollary 15.20. That there are no further (independent) relations follows from the fact that we can now write every surface uniquely as $(\\#_g T^2) = \\Sigma_g$, or $(\\#_g T^2) \\# \\mathbb{RP}^2 = N_{2g+1}$, or $(\\#_g T^2) \\# \\mathbb{RP}^2 \\# \\mathbb{RP}^2 = N_{2g+2}$, all of which are distinct.

name: Evenly Covered
statement:
Fix a map $\pi : Y \to X$. A subset $U \subset X$ is said to be evenly covered if there is a discrete space $S$ and a homeomorphism $\psi$ making the following diagram commute:

$U \times S \xrightarrow{\pi_U} U$
$\psi \cong \quad \quad \quad \quad id$
$\pi^{-1}(U) \xrightarrow{\pi} U$

name: Covering Map
statement: We say that $\\pi : Y \\to X$ is a covering map if every point in $X$ has an evenly covered neighbourhood. We also say that $Y$ is a covering space of the base $X$.

name: Universal Cover
statement: Fix a path-connected space $X$. A covering map $\\pi : Y \\to X$ is the universal cover of $X$ if $Y$ is simply-connected.

name: Circle Covering
statement:
The following is a covering map:

$\pi : R \to S^1 \cong R/Z$
$t \mapsto [t]$.

And it is in fact the universal cover of $S^1$.
proof:
Any interval $(a, b) \subset R$ of length less than 1 will project to an interval $I$ in $S^1$ whose preimage is the union

$\coprod_{k\in Z} (a + k, b + k)$,

meaning that $I$ is evenly covered. The second claim follows from the fact that $R$ is contractible and thus simply-connected.

name: Surface Connected Sum
statement: Let $A$ and $B$ be surfaces, not necessarily closed, possibly with boundary. We define $A\\#B$ as follows. Find a closed disc $D_A \\subset A$ and a closed disc $D_B \\subset B$ both contained in the interior (i.e. disjoint from the boundary). Remove their interiors, and identify $\\partial D_A \\subset A$ with $\\partial D_M \\subset M$ via your favourite homeomorphism.

name: Complex Universal Cover
statement:
In complex coordinates, the universal cover of Lemma 16.4 reads:

$\exp : R \to S^1 \subset C$

$t \mapsto e^{2\pi it}$.

name: k-Sheeted Covering
statement:
Fix a positive integer $k$. Then, the following map is a covering space with $k$ sheets:

$\pi_k : S^1 \simeq R/Z \to S^1 \simeq R/Z$

$[t] \mapsto [kt]$.

Alternatively, in complex coordinates, the map $\pi_k$ can be expressed as:

$f_k : S^1 \to S^1 \subset C$

$z \mapsto z^k$.
proof: Let $I \\in S^1 \\simeq R/Z$ be an interval of length $h < 1/k$. Then its preimage under $\\pi_k$ consists of $k$ disjoint intervals of length $h/k$, proving the evenly covered property.

name: Pushforward Subgroup
statement:
The pushforward

$(f_k)_* : \pi_1(S^1, 1) \simeq Z \to \pi_1(S^1, 1)$

sends the generator $a = [\text{id}_{S^1}]$ to $a^k$. In particular, the image of $(f_k)_*$ is the subgroup $kZ$.

name: Restriction Property
statement:
Let $\pi : Y \to X$ be a covering map and $A \subset X$ a subspace. Then the restriction

$\pi : \pi^{-1}(A) \to A$

is a covering map.
proof: Given a point $p \\in A$, take an evenly covered neighbourhood $U \\subset X$. This means that $\\pi^{-1}(U)$ is homeomorphic to $U \\times S$, with $S$ discrete. It follows that $\\pi^{-1}(A \\cap U)$ is homeomorphic to $(U \\cap A) \\times S$, so $U \\cap A$ is an evenly covered neighbourhood of $p$ in $A$.

name: Evenly-Covered Basis
statement: Let $\\pi : Y \\to X$ be a covering map. Then the evenly-covered opens in $X$ form a basis of the topology.
proof: Given a point $x \\in X$, take an evenly covered neighbourhood $U \\subset X$. Every neighbourhood of $x$ contained in $U$ is evenly covered, so all of them form a basis at $x$.

name: Sheets Form Basis
statement: Let $\\pi : Y \\to X$ be a covering map. Then the sheets in $Y$ over evenly-covered opens of $X$ form a basis of the topology of $Y$.
proof: Given a point $y \\in Y$, take an evenly covered neighbourhood $U \\subset X$ of $\\pi(y)$. Then we can take the sheet $U' \\subset Y$ of $U$ that contains $y$. Every neighbourhood $V$ of $y$ contained in $U'$ is itself a sheet over its projection $\\pi(V)$, so all of them together form a basis of the topology at $y$.

name: Covering Maps Open
statement: Let $\\pi : Y \\to X$ be a covering map. Then, it is an open map (it takes opens to opens).
proof: It is enough to show that it maps basis elements of the topology in $Y$ to opens in $X$. This is clear, since a sheet $V$ over an open $U$ is mapped to $U$.

name: Hausdorff Preservation
statement: Let $\\pi : Y \\to X$ be a covering space. Then $Y$ is Hausdorff if and only if $X$ is Hausdorff.
proof: Suppose $X$ is Hausdorff. Let $y$ and $y'$ be two distinct points in $Y$. We must show that a pair of disjoint neighbourhoods exists. There are two cases. The first is that $y$ and $y'$ project to the same point $x = \\pi(y) = \\pi(y')$. Then we take $U$ an evenly-covered neighbourhood of $x$ and we let $V$ and $V'$ be the sheets over it passing via $y$ and $y'$, respectively. The evenly covered condition says that $\\pi|_V : V \\to U$ and $\\pi|_{V'} : V' \\to U$ are homeomorphisms, and from this it follows that $V$ and $V'$ must be disjoint, since $y$ and $y'$ are distinct. The second case is that $x = \\pi(y)$ and $x' = \\pi(x')$ are distinct. Then they have disjoint neighbourhoods $U$ and $U'$, so their preimages are disjoint.\n\nAssume now that $Y$ is Hausdorff. Then, given $x$ and $x'$ in $X$, we can pick arbitrary preimages $y$ and $y'$, find disjoint neighbourhoods $V$ and $V'$ that are also sheets, and deduce that $\\pi(V)$ and $\\pi(V')$ are disjoint neighbourhods of $x$ and $x'$ in $X$.

name: Second Countability
statement: Let $\\pi : Y \\to X$ be a covering space with countably many sheets. Then $X$ is second countable if and only if $Y$ is second countable.
proof: If $X$ has a countable basis, it has a countable basis consisting of evenly-covered opens. Each such open has countably many preimages. The product of two countable sets is countable, so the basis of $Y$ consisting of sheets is also countable. For the converse, just project the basis of sheets to the basis of evenly-covered opens.

name: Manifold Preservation
statement: Let $\\pi : Y \\to X$ be a covering space with countably many sheets. Then $Y$ is a manifold if and only if $X$ is a manifold.
proof: X and Y are locally homeomorphic, so one is locally euclidean if and only if the other one is. Hausdorffness and second countability we addressed above.

name: Covering Surface Preservation
statement: The covering spaces of a surface are also surfaces.
proof: This follows directly from Lemma 16.14, which states that if $\\pi : Y \\to X$ is a covering space with countably many sheets, then $Y$ is a manifold if and only if $X$ is a manifold. Since surfaces are 2-dimensional manifolds, the covering spaces of a surface are also surfaces.

name: Cell Structure Lifting
statement: Let $X$ be a CW complex and let $\\pi : Y \\to X$ be a covering space. Then, there is a unique cell structure on $Y$ compatible with $\\pi$. Concretely, this means that for each characteristic map $\\tilde{\\psi} : D^n \\to Y$ of a cell, the projected map $\\psi := \\pi \\circ \\tilde{\\psi} : D^n \\to X$ should also be a characteristic map.
proof:
The desired conclusion forces us to define the $n$-th skeleton $Y_n$ as the preimage of $X_n$. We will now explain how $Y_n$ is obtained from $Y_{n-1}$ by attaching $n$-cells, but we will not be able to complete the argument rigorously, since it needs the results of Section 17.1.

The general idea is that, given a cell $\psi : D^n \to X$ passing through $x \in X_{n-1}$ and a point $y \in \pi^{-1}(x)$, there is a unique cell $\tilde{\psi} : D^n \to Y$ passing through $y$ and satisfying $\pi \circ \tilde{\psi} = \psi$. This means that $\tilde{\psi}$ is a lift of $\psi$. This concept is introduced in Definition 16.17 below and most of covering space theory boils down to understanding it well.

Here is thus the proof. The existence of a unique lift $\tilde{\psi}$ passing through $y$ is a consequence of the lifting criterion (Theorem 17.1), using the fact that $D^n$ is simply-connected. Since the restriction of $\psi$ to the boundary is the attaching map, which takes values in $X_{n-1}$, it follows that $\tilde{\psi}$ restricted to the boundary takes values in $Y_{n-1}$. With this, we have exhibited $Y_n$ as a union of cells.

It remains to show that $Y$ indeed has the quotient topology inherited from the disjoint union of all cells, up to the identifications given by the attaching. This we can check locally: given a point $y \in Y$, we pick a small open $U$ intersecting only cells incident to $y$. We can moreover assume that $U$ is one of the sheets over the evenly covered $\pi(U)$. Since $\pi(U)$ is obtained from the (parts of) cells it intersects by quotienting, the same is true for $U$.

name: Lift of Map
statement:
Fix a map $\pi : Y \to X$. A map $\tilde{f} : A \to Y$ is a lift of $f : A \to X$ with respect to $\pi$ if $f = \pi \circ \tilde{f}$.

Identically, the three maps fit into the commutative diagram:

$\begin{array}{ccc}
 & Y & \\
 & \downarrow^\pi & \\
 & X & \\
\tilde{f}\nearrow & \uparrow^f & \\
& A &
\end{array}$

name: Pointed Lift
statement: Fix a map $\\pi : (Y, y) \\to (X, x)$. A map $\\tilde{f} : (A, a) \\to (Y, y)$ is a lift of $f : (A, a) \\to (X, x)$ with respect to $\\pi$ if $f = \\pi \\circ \\tilde{f}$.

name: Lift Pushforward
statement: Suppose $f : A \\to X$ admits a lift $\\tilde{f}$ with respect to $\\pi : Y \\to X$. Then $[f] \\in [A, X]$ is the image of $[\\tilde{f}] \\in [A, Y]$ via $\\pi_* : [A, Y] \\to [A, X]$.
proof: The result follows from the computation $[f] = [\\pi \\circ \\tilde{f}] = [\\pi] \\circ [\\tilde{f}] = \\pi_*([\\tilde{f}])$.
preconditions: map satisfies the path lifting property

name: Lift Image Relation
statement: Suppose $\\gamma : (S^1, 1) \\to (X, x)$ admits a lift $\\tilde{\\gamma} : (S^1, 1) \\to (Y, y)$ with respect to $\\pi : (Y, y) \\to (X, x)$. Then $[\\gamma] \\in \\pi_1(X, x)$ is the image of $[\\tilde{\\gamma}] \\in \\pi_1(Y, y)$ via $\\pi_* : \\pi_1(Y, y) \\to \\pi_1(X, x)$.
proof: This follows directly from Lemma 16.19, which states that if $f : A \\to X$ admits a lift $\\tilde{f}$ with respect to $\\pi : Y \\to X$, then $[f] \\in [A, X]$ is the image of $[\\tilde{f}] \\in [A, Y]$ via $\\pi_* : [A, Y] \\to [A, X]$. Here we apply this result to the specific case where $A = S^1$ and the maps are pointed.

name: Non-liftable Homotopy
statement: Let $A$ and $Y$ be the point and $X$ be $\\mathbb{R}$. We let $f$ and $\\pi$ be the map with image $0 \\in \\mathbb{R}$. Then $f$ lifts to the unique map $A \\to Y$. Any other map $f'$, with image different from $0$, is homotopic to $f$, but has no lift.

name: Homotopy Lifting Property
preconditions: map satisfies the homotopy lifting property

name: Unique Homotopy Lifting
statement: A map $\\pi : Y \\to X$ satisfies the unique homotopy lifting property if the homotopy lifting property holds and, moreover, the lift $\\tilde{F}$ is unique.
preconditions: map satisfies the homotopy lifting property

name: Path Lifting Property
preconditions: map satisfies the path lifting property

name: Unique Homotopy Lifting
statement: Covering spaces satisfy the unique homotopy lifting property (UHLP).
proof: One first shows that a path $\\gamma$ can be lifted uniquely, once we choose a lift $\\tilde{\\gamma}(0)$ of its initial point $\\gamma(0)$. The main insight is that this is true locally. Concretely: According to the Lebesgue covering lemma, the domain of $\\gamma$ can be divided into intervals $I_i$ so that $\\gamma|_{I_i}$ takes values in an evenly-covered open $U_i$. We can thus consider $U_0 \\ni \\gamma(0)$ and the sheet $U'_0$ over it containing $\\tilde{\\gamma}(0)$. We then use the homeomorphism $\\phi$ between $U_0$ and $U'_0$ to define $\\tilde{\\gamma}|_{I_0} = \\phi \\circ \\gamma|_{I_0}$. Observe that this is the unique way to define a continuous lift, since all other preimages of $\\gamma|_{I_0}$ live in other sheets, which are disconnected from $\\tilde{\\gamma}(0)$. One then continues by induction on $i$.\n\nFor the general case, where we have a homotopy $F$ and a lift $\\tilde{f}$ of $f = F(-, 0)$, one argues similarly. The idea is that one can use the compactness of $[0, 1]$ to cover the domain $A$ with little opens $V$ so that $F|_{V \\times [0,1]}$, which we can think of as a family of paths parametrised by $V$, can be lifted at once, using our earlier reasoning. Uniqueness implies that all these local lifts agree on overlaps.
preconditions: map satisfies the unique homotopy lifting property

name: Uniqueness of Lifts
statement: Suppose $\\pi : (Y, y) \\to (X, x)$ is a covering space. Let $A$ be path-connected. Then, any two lifts $h, h' : (A, a) \\to (Y, y)$ of $f : (A, a) \\to (X, x)$ agree.
proof: Since $A$ is path-connected, given any point $b$ we can find a path $\\gamma : [0, 1] \\to A$ that connects $a$ to $b$. Then we observe that $h \\circ \\gamma$ and $h' \\circ \\gamma$ are both lifts of $f \\circ \\gamma$. Since $\\pi$ satisfies the unique path lifting property, we deduce that $h \\circ \\gamma = h' \\circ \\gamma$. In particular, $h(b) = h \\circ \\gamma(1) = h' \\circ \\gamma(1) = h'(b)$. Since $b$ was arbitrary, the claim follows.

name: Constant Map Lifting
statement: Suppose $\\pi : (Y, y) \\to (X, x)$ is a covering space. Let $A$ be path-connected and $f : (A, a) \\to (X, x)$ be the constant map. Then the unique lift of $f$ is the constant map with image $y$.
proof: This follows directly from Lemma 16.26, as the constant map with image $y$ is a lift of the constant map $f$.

name: Holonomy
statement:
Let $\pi : Y \to X$ be a covering map and $\gamma : [0, 1] \to X$ a path from $a$ to $b$. The holonomy of $\pi$ along $\gamma$ is the map:

$\text{hol}_\gamma : \pi^{-1}(a) \to \pi^{-1}(b)$

defined by $z \mapsto \tilde{\gamma}(1)$, where $\tilde{\gamma}$ is the unique lift of $\gamma$ starting at $z \in \pi^{-1}(a)$.
preconditions: map satisfies the unique homotopy lifting property
map satisfies the path lifting property

name: Constant Path Holonomy
statement: The holonomy $\\text{hol}_{c_a}$ of a constant path is the identity.
proof: By Corollary 16.27, constant paths lift to constant paths. Therefore, if $c_a$ is a constant path at $a$, and $z \\in \\pi^{-1}(a)$, then the lift $\\tilde{c_a}$ starting at $z$ is the constant path at $z$. Thus $\\text{hol}_{c_a}(z) = \\tilde{c_a}(1) = z$, showing that $\\text{hol}_{c_a}$ is the identity map on $\\pi^{-1}(a)$.

name: Holonomy Homotopy Invariance
statement: If $\\gamma$ and $\\nu$ are homotopic relative endpoints, $\\text{hol}_{\\gamma} = \\text{hol}_{\\nu}$.
proof:
Let $a$ and $b$ be the endpoints of $\gamma$ and $\nu$. Fix a point $z \in \pi^{-1}(a)$. By assumption we have a homotopy relative endpoints $\Gamma$ between $\gamma$ and $\nu$. The unique homotopy lifting property yields unique lifts $\tilde{\gamma}, \tilde{\nu} : [0, 1] \to Y$ starting at $z$. The UHLP also lifts $\Gamma$ to a homotopy $\tilde{\Gamma} : [0, 1] \times [0, 1] \to Y$ starting at $\tilde{\gamma}$.

Since $\tilde{\Gamma}(-, 1)$ starts at $z$ and is a lift of $\nu$, it must be $\tilde{\nu}$, by uniqueness of the lift. Moreover, since $\Gamma(1, -)$ and $\Gamma(0, -)$ are constant (because $\Gamma$ is a homotopy relative endpoints), their lifts are also constant (Corollary 16.27). This implies that $\tilde{\Gamma}$ is also a homotopy relative endpoints. In particular, the endpoints of $\tilde{\gamma}$ and $\tilde{\nu}$ are the same.

We have thus shown that $\text{hol}_{\gamma}$ only depends on $[\gamma]$. This means that the holonomy is best understood through the fundamental groupoid $\Pi_1(X)$.
preconditions: map is a homotopy relative endpoints

name: Holonomy Composition
statement: Let $[\\gamma] \\in \\pi_1(X, a, b)$ and $[\\nu] \\in \\pi_1(X, b, c)$. Then $\\text{hol}_{\\nu \\cdot \\gamma} = \\text{hol}_{\\nu} \\circ \\text{hol}_{\\gamma} : \\pi^{-1}(a) \\to \\pi^{-1}(c)$.
proof:
Suppose $z \in \pi^{-1}(a)$. Let $\tilde{\gamma}$ be the lift of $\gamma$ starting at $a$. By definition, it finishes at

$w := \tilde{\gamma}(1) = \text{hol}_{\gamma}(z) \in \pi^{-1}(b)$.

We can then take the lift $\tilde{\nu}$ of $\nu$, starting at $w$. It ends up in

$\tilde{\nu}(1) = \text{hol}_{\nu}(w) = \text{hol}_{\nu} \circ \text{hol}_{\gamma}(z) \in \pi^{-1}(c)$.

The conclusion follows from the fact that $\tilde{\nu} \cdot \tilde{\gamma}$ is a lift (and thus the unique lift) of $\nu \cdot \gamma$ starting at $z$, so:

$\text{hol}_{\nu\cdot\gamma}(z) = (\tilde{\nu} \cdot \tilde{\gamma})(1) = \tilde{\nu}(1) = \text{hol}_{\nu} \circ \text{hol}_{\gamma}(z)$.

name: Holonomy Inverse
statement: \\text{hol}_{\\gamma} is the inverse of \\text{hol}_{\\bar{\\gamma}}. In particular, the two are bijections.
proof: Since $[\\gamma]$ and $[\\bar{\\gamma}]$ are inverses we have that $\\text{hol}_{\\bar{\\gamma}} \\circ \\text{hol}_{\\gamma} = \\text{hol}_{c_a}$, which is the identity. The same holds for $\\text{hol}_{\\gamma} \\circ \\text{hol}_{\\bar{\\gamma}}$.

name: Holonomy Functor
statement:
Let $\pi : Y \to X$ be a covering space. There is a functor

$\text{hol} : \Pi_1(X) \to \text{Set}$

that sends:

$\bullet$ A point $x \in X$ to its fibre $\pi^{-1}(x)$.
$\bullet$ A class $[\gamma] \in \pi_1(X, x, x')$ to the bijection $\text{hol}_{\gamma}$.
proof: This follows directly from the properties established in Lemma 16.30, Lemma 16.31, and Corollary 16.32. Lemma 16.30 shows that holonomy depends only on the homotopy class of paths, making it well-defined on morphisms in $\\Pi_1(X)$. Lemma 16.31 establishes that holonomy preserves composition, and Corollary 16.32 confirms that it preserves inverses. These properties together ensure that hol is indeed a functor from the fundamental groupoid to the category of sets.

name: Constant Sheet Count
statement: Let $\\pi : Y \\to X$ be a covering map, with $X$ path-connected. Then, the cardinality of $\\pi^{-1}(a)$ is independent of the point $a \\in X$.
proof: Suppose $a$ and $b$ are points in $X$ and consider a path $\\gamma$ from $a$ to $b$. Then $\\text{hol}_{\\gamma}$ is the required bijection between their fibres. The idea of the proof is shown in Figure 16.4.

name: Cell Lifting
statement: Let $\\pi : Y \\to X$ be a covering space with $k$ sheets. Suppose $X$ is a cell complex. Then each cell in $X$ lifts to $k$ distinct cells in $Y$.
proof: This result follows from Proposition 16.16, which states that a covering space $Y$ of a CW complex $X$ has a unique cell structure compatible with $\\pi$. Since $X$ is path-connected, by Proposition 16.34, the cardinality of the fiber $\\pi^{-1}(p)$ is constant and equal to $k$ for any point $p \\in X$. Each cell in $X$ therefore has exactly $k$ preimages in $Y$, corresponding to the $k$ sheets of the covering.

name: Covering Injectivity
statement: Let $\\pi : (Y, y) \\to (X, x)$ be a covering space. Then $\\pi_* : \\pi_1(Y, y) \\to \\pi_1(X, x)$ is injective.
proof: Consider a loop $\\tilde{\\gamma} : (S^1, 1) \\to (Y, y)$ and write $\\gamma := \\pi \\circ \\tilde{\\gamma}$ for its projection. By construction $\\tilde{\\gamma}$ lifts $\\gamma$. The class $[\\tilde{\\gamma}]$ being in the kernel of $\\pi_*$ means that $\\pi_*[\\tilde{\\gamma}] = [\\gamma]$ is the trivial class $[c_x]$ in $\\pi_1(X, x)$.\n\nLet $\\Gamma$ be a homotopy relative endpoints, between $\\gamma$ and $c_x$. According to the homotopy lifting property (Theorem 16.25), $\\Gamma$ can be lifted to a homotopy $\\tilde{\\Gamma} : [0, 1] \\times [0, 1] \\to Y$ with $\\tilde{\\Gamma}(-, 0) = \\tilde{\\gamma}$. Using Lemma 16.30 we moreover see that $\\tilde{\\Gamma}$ is relative to endpoints as well. Lastly, we observe that $\\tilde{\\Gamma}(-, 1)$ is the constant map with value $y$, since $\\Gamma(-, 1)$ was the constant loop at $x$. I.e., we have shown that $[\\tilde{\\gamma}] = [c_y]$, and thus shown that the kernel of $\\pi_*$ is trivial.

name: Holy Map
statement: Let $\\pi : (Y, y) \\to (X, x)$ be a pointed covering space. We define a map of sets: $\\text{holy} : s^{-1}(x) \\to Y$ by setting $\\text{holy}([\\gamma]) := \\text{hol}_{\\gamma}(y) \\in \\pi^{-1}(\\gamma(1))$. This is well-defined by Lemma 16.30.

name: Holy Properties
statement:
Let $\pi : (Y, y) \to (X, x)$ be a pointed covering space, with $X$ and $Y$ path-connected. Then, the following statements hold:

$\bullet$ The function $\text{holy}$ is surjective.

$\bullet$ Its restriction to $\pi_1(X, x, a)$ is surjective onto the fibre $\pi^{-1}(a)$.

$\bullet$ Write $H \subset \pi_1(X, x)$ for the preimage of $x$ via $\text{holy}$. Then, $H$ is a subgroup.

$\bullet$ Two elements $[\gamma], [\nu] \in \pi_1(X, x, a)$ have the same image if and only if $[\bar{\gamma}][\nu] \in H$.
proof:
For the first item, pick a point $z \in Y$. Since $Y$ is path-connected, there is a path $\tilde{\gamma} : [0, 1] \to Y$ from $y$ to $z$. It lifts its projection $\gamma := \pi \circ \tilde{\gamma}$, which is a path starting at $x$ and finishing at some $a := \pi(z)$. It follows that $\text{holy}([\gamma]) = z$. The second item is an immediate consequence.

For the third item, we must show that $H$ contains the identity $[c_x]$, inverses, and compositions. To show $\text{holy}([c_x]) = y$ we just observe that $c_x$ lifts to the constant path at $y$. Regarding inverses, we assume $[\alpha] \in H$, meaning that $\text{holy}([\alpha]) = y$. Then we use Lemma 16.31 and compute:

$y = \text{holy}([c_x]) = \text{holy}([\bar{\alpha}][\alpha]) = \text{hol}_{\bar{\alpha}\cdot\alpha}(y) = \text{hol}_{\bar{\alpha}} \circ \text{hol}_{\alpha}(y) = \text{hol}_{\bar{\alpha}}(y)$,

which shows that $[\bar{\alpha}] \in H$. The proof for compositions is similar, if we assume $[\alpha], [\beta] \in H$ we get:

$\text{holy}([\beta][\alpha]) = \text{hol}_{\beta} \circ \text{hol}_{\alpha}(y) = \text{hol}_{\beta} \circ \text{hol}_{\alpha}(y) = \text{hol}_{\beta}(y) = y$,

which shows $[\beta][\alpha] \in H$.

For the last claim denote $z = \text{holy}([\gamma])$. For the if direction we write:

$\text{holy}([\nu]) = \text{holy}([\gamma][\bar{\gamma}][\nu]) = \text{hol}_{\gamma} \circ \text{hol}_{\bar{\gamma}\cdot\nu}(y) = \text{hol}_{\gamma}(y) = \text{holy}([\gamma])$.

For the only if:

$\text{holy}([\bar{\gamma}][\nu]) = \text{hol}_{\bar{\gamma}} \circ \text{hol}_{\nu}(y) = \text{hol}_{\bar{\gamma}}(z) = y$.

name: Covering Space Bijection
statement:
Let $\pi : (Y, y) \to (X, x)$ be a pointed covering space, with $X$ and $Y$ path-connected. Write $H \subset \pi_1(X, x)$ for the preimage of $x$ via $\text{hol}_y$. Then:

$\bullet$ $\text{hol}_y : s^{-1}(x)/H \to Y$ is a bijection.
$\bullet$ $H$ is the image of $\pi_1(Y, y)$ via $\pi_*$.
proof:
The first claim is immediate from the definition of $H$ (see items (3) and (4) in Lemma 16.38).

For the second claim, we first show that $H$ is contained in the image. Take then a class $[\gamma] \in H$ and let $\tilde{\gamma} : [0, 1] \to Y$ be its lift starting at $y$. By definition $y = \text{hol}_y([\gamma]) = \tilde{\gamma}(1)$, meaning that $\tilde{\gamma}$ is a loop and thus $[\tilde{\gamma}] \in \pi_1(Y, y)$. It follows that $[\gamma] = \pi_*[\tilde{\gamma}]$.

For the converse inclusion, take some $[\tilde{\gamma}] \in \pi_1(Y, y)$ and let $[\gamma] := \pi_*[\tilde{\gamma}] \in \pi_1(X, x)$ be its projection. It follows that $\text{hol}_y([\gamma]) = y$, so $[\gamma] \in H$.

name: Universal Cover Bijection
statement:
Let $\pi : (Y, y) \to (X, x)$ be the universal cover. Then the map

$\text{hol}_y : s^{-1}(x) \to Y$

is a bijection.
proof: Since $Y$ is the universal cover, $\\pi_1(Y, y) = \\{e\\}$ is the trivial group. By Corollary 16.39, $H = \\pi_*(\\pi_1(Y, y)) = \\{e\\}$ is also the trivial group. Therefore, $s^{-1}(x)/H = s^{-1}(x)$, and the result follows directly from the first part of Corollary 16.39.

name: Fiber Cardinality
statement: Let $H = \\pi_*(\\pi_1(Y, y))$ be the subgroup associated to the pointed covering space $\\pi : (Y, y) \\to (X, x)$, with $X$ path-connected. Then the cardinality of the fibre $\\pi^{-1}(x)$ is the index of $H$ in $\\pi_1(X, x)$.
proof: Recall that the index is the cardinality of $\\pi_1(X, x)/H$. The claim is then immediate from Corollary 16.39.

name: Lifting Criterion
statement:
Let $\pi : (Y, y) \to (X, x)$ be a pointed covering map and $f : (A, a) \to (X, x)$ a pointed map. Suppose moreover that $A$ is path-connected and locally path-connected. Then:

$\bullet$ $f$ admits a lift $\tilde{f} : (A, a) \to (Y, y)$ if and only if $f_*(\pi_1(A, a)) \subset \pi_*(\pi_1(Y, y))$.
$\bullet$ This lift is unique.
proof:
The only if direction follows from the identity $f = \pi \circ \tilde{f}$:

$f_*(\pi_1(A, a)) = \pi_* \circ \tilde{f}_*(\pi_1(A, a)) \subset \pi_*(\pi_1(Y, y))$.

For the if direction we lift paths. Observe first that we must set $\tilde{f}(a) = y$, due to the pointed condition. Given any other $a' \in A$, we pick $[\gamma] \in \pi_1(A, a, a')$, write $x' := f(a')$, consider the pushforward $[f \circ \gamma] \in \pi_1(X, x, x')$, and set

$\tilde{f}(a') := \text{hol}_{f \circ\gamma}(y)$.

We must now show this definition does not depend on our choice of $\gamma$. First note that, according to Lemma 16.30, $\text{hol}_{f \circ\gamma}$ does not depend on the representative $f \circ \gamma$, only on the class $f_*[\gamma]$. Secondly, the choice of class $[\gamma]$ also does not matter. If we choose some other $[\nu] \in \pi_1(A, a, a')$, we have that

$\text{hol}_{f \circ\nu}(y) = \text{hol}_{f \circ(\gamma\cdot\bar{\gamma}\cdot\nu)}(y) = \text{hol}_{f \circ\gamma} \circ \text{hol}_{f \circ(\bar{\gamma}\cdot\nu)}(y) = \text{hol}_{f \circ\gamma}(y)$

where we have used the assumption $f_*[\bar{\gamma} \cdot \nu] \in \pi_*(\pi_1(Y, y))$ and invoked Lemma 16.38 to see that the holonomy along it is trivial.

We have thus shown that $\tilde{f}$ is well-defined. We must now show that it is continuous. This follows from the evenly-covered property. Indeed, $Y$ has a basis of neighbourhoods $V$ such that $V$ is a sheet over the evenly covered $\pi(V)$. Given $a' \in A$ with $\tilde{f}(a') \in V$ we have that $f^{-1}(\pi(V))$ is an open containing $a'$, by continuity of $A$. It therefore contains an open $U \ni a'$ that is path-connected. We claim that $\tilde{f}|_U$ amounts to mapping $U$ to $\pi(V)$ using $f$, and then lifting to $V$ using the homeomorphism between the two. This will then establish continuity, since $\tilde{f}(U) \subset V$.

To prove the claim, observe that $a'' \in U$ can be joined to $a'$ using a path $\nu$ in $U$. Let $\gamma$ be a path connecting $a$ to $a''$. Then

$\tilde{f}(a'') := \text{hol}_{f \circ(\nu\cdot\gamma)}(y) = \text{hol}_{f \circ\nu} \circ \text{hol}_{f \circ\gamma}(y) = \text{hol}_{f \circ\nu}(\tilde{f}(a'))$

which proves the claim, since $f \circ \nu$ takes values in $\pi(V)$.

To establish uniqueness of $\tilde{f}$, do note that we did not have any choice in its construction, due to the uniqueness of the path lifting property for covering spaces.

name: Simply-Connected Lifting
statement: Let $p : (Y, y) \\to (X, x)$ be a covering map. Let $f : (A, a) \\to (X, x)$ be a map with $A$ path-connected and locally path-connected. If $A$ is simply-connected, $f$ admits a lift.
proof: Since $A$ is simply-connected, $\\pi_1(A, a) = \\{e\\}$ is the trivial group. Therefore, $f_*(\\pi_1(A, a)) = \\{e\\} \\subset \\pi_*(\\pi_1(Y, y))$ for any covering space $Y$. By Theorem 17.1, $f$ admits a lift.

name: Category of Subgroups
statement:
Given a group $G$, we can consider the category $\text{Subgrp}(G)$ defined by:

$\bullet$ $\text{Ob}(\text{Subgrp}(G))$ is the set of subgroups of $G$.

$\bullet$ For each two subgroups $H, L \subset G$, we say that $\text{Hom}_{\text{Subgrp}(G)}(H, L) \simeq \{.\}$ if $H \subset L$, and empty otherwise.

name: Subgroup Category Properties
statement:
Prove that:

$\bullet$ The coproduct of $A, B$ in $\text{Subgrp}(G)$ is the (set theoretical) intersection.

$\bullet$ The product of $A, B$ in $\text{Subgrp}(G)$ is the subgroup of $G$ generated by the elements of $A$ and $B$.

$\bullet$ The pushout of a diagram $A \leftarrow I \rightarrow B$ is the product of $A$ and $B$ (i.e. the same as the product).

$\bullet$ Find a concrete example of $G, A$ and $B$ showing that the inclusion functor $\text{Subgrp}(G) \rightarrow \text{Grp}$ does not preserve products.

name: Covering Map Morphism
statement: Let $\\pi : (Y, y) \\rightarrow (X, x)$ and $\\pi' : (Y', y') \\rightarrow (X, x)$ be pointed covering spaces. A morphism of covering maps from $\\pi$ to $\\pi'$ is a pointed map $f : (Y, y) \\rightarrow (Y', y')$ such that $\\pi = \\pi' \\circ f$.

name: Covering Spaces Category
statement:
Let $(X, x)$ be a path-connected pointed space. We define the category of pointed covering spaces $\text{Cover}(X, x)$ of $(X, x)$ as follows:

$\bullet$ $\text{Ob}(\text{Cover}(X, x))$ is the class of all pointed covering maps $f : (Y, y) \rightarrow (X, x)$ with $Y$ path-connected.

$\bullet$ Given two pointed covering maps $\pi : (Y, y) \rightarrow (X, x)$ and $\pi' : (Y', y') \rightarrow (X, x)$, we let $\text{Hom}_{\text{Cover}(X,x)}(\pi, \pi')$ be the set of all morphisms from $\pi$ to $\pi'$.

name: Galois Correspondence
statement:
Suppose $(X, x)$ is path-connected and locally simply-connected. Then, the Galois functor

$G : \text{Cover}(X, x) \rightarrow \text{Subgrp}(\pi_1(X, x))$

is an equivalence of categories.
preconditions: map is an equivalence of categories

name: Locally Simply-Connected Space
statement: A space $X$ is locally simply-connected if every point in $X$ has a system of simply-connected neighbourhods.

name: Galois Functor
statement:
The Galois functor $G : \text{Cover}(X, x) \rightarrow \text{Subgrp}(\pi_1(X, x))$:

$\bullet$ Takes a pointed covering map $\pi : (Y, y) \rightarrow (X, x)$ to the subgroup $\pi_*(\pi_1(Y, y)) \subset \pi_1(X, x)$.

$\bullet$ Takes a morphism of pointed covering spaces $f : (Y, y) \rightarrow (Y', y')$ to the inclusion $\pi_*(\pi_1(Y, y)) \rightarrow \pi'_*(\pi_1(Y', y'))$.

name: Covering Space Existence
statement: Given a subgroup $H \\subset \\pi_1(X, x)$, there is a pointed covering map $\\pi : (Y, y) \\rightarrow (X, x)$ with $H = \\pi_*(\\pi_1(Y, y))$.

name: Covering Morphism Properties
statement:
Fix elements $\pi : (Y, y) \rightarrow (X, x)$ and $\pi' : (Y', y') \rightarrow (X, x)$ in $\text{Cover}(X, x)$. Let $f : (Y, y) \rightarrow (Y', y')$ be a morphism. Then:

$\bullet$ $f$ is itself a covering map.
$\bullet$ $f_* : \pi_1(Y, y) \rightarrow \pi_1(Y', y')$ is injective.
$\bullet$ $\pi'_* \circ f_* = \iota \circ \pi_*$, where $\iota$ is the inclusion $\pi_*(\pi_1(Y, y)) \rightarrow \pi'_*(\pi_1(Y', y'))$.
proof: Given a point $p \\in X$, we can find a neighbourhood $U \\subset X$ that is evenly covered for $\\pi$. Similarly, there is a neighbourhood $U' \\subset X$ that is evenly covered for $\\pi'$. Their intersection $V := U \\cap U'$ is evenly covered for both, thanks to Lemma 16.8. We therefore have that there are discrete spaces $S$ and $S'$ such that $\\pi^{-1}(V) \\simeq U \\times S$ and $(\\pi')^{-1}(V) \\simeq U \\times S'$. By continuity of $f$, we deduce that each $U \\times \\{s\\}$ is mapped to some $U \\times \\{s'\\}$, i.e., $f$ maps sheets to sheets. Moreover, the morphism property $\\pi = \\pi' \\circ f$ implies that the restricted map $f : U \\times \\{s\\} \\rightarrow U \\times \\{s'\\}$ is a homeomorphism. This implies that each sheet in $Y'$ is evenly covered by sheets of $Y$, proving the first claim.\n\nThe second item then follows from Proposition 16.36 and the third by the equality $\\pi' \\circ f = \\pi$.

name: Covering Space Isomorphism
statement:
Fix elements $\pi : (Y, y) \to (X, x)$ and $\pi' : (Y', y') \to (X, x)$ in $\text{Cover}(X, x)$. Then:

$\bullet$ There is at most one morphism from $\pi$ to $\pi'$.
$\bullet$ There is a morphism from $\pi$ to $\pi'$ if and only if $\pi_*(\pi_1(Y, y))$ is a subgroup of $\pi'_*(\pi_1(Y', y'))$.
$\bullet$ In particular, the two covering spaces are isomorphic if and only if $\pi_*(\pi_1(Y, y)) = \pi'_*(\pi_1(Y', y'))$.
proof:
Suppose $f$ is a morphism from $\pi$ to $\pi'$. Then $f$ is a lift of the identity along $\pi'$. It follows that $f$ is unique, due to the lifting criterion (Theorem 17.1).

The only if direction of the second item follows from Proposition 17.11. For the if direction we apply the lifting criterion. First note that the assumptions of the theorem hold: (1) elements of $\text{Cover}(X, x)$ are path-connected and locally simply-connected, since $X$ itself is locally simply-connected, and (2) we have the inclusion $\pi_*(\pi_1(Y, y)) \subset \pi'_*(\pi_1(Y', y'))$. It follows that there is a lift of $\pi$ along $\pi'$. This is precisely what a morphism is.

For the last item, observe that the assumption means that there is a morphism $f$ from $\pi$ to $\pi'$ and a morphism $g$ from $\pi'$ to $\pi$. Then $g \circ f$ lifts $\pi$ along itself. Since $\text{id}_Y$ also lifts $\pi$ along itself, the two must agree. The same reasoning shows that $f \circ g = \text{id}_{Y'}$, so $f$ and $g$ are inverses.

name: Fundamental Groupoid Topology
statement:
Let $X$ be a locally simply-connected space. The topology in $\Pi_1(X)$ is generated by the basis:

$V_{[\gamma],U_s,U_t} := \{[\beta][\gamma][\alpha]^{-1} \mid [\alpha] \in \pi_1(U_s, \gamma(0), q), [\beta] \in \pi_1(U_t, \gamma(1), p)\}$

where $[\gamma] \in \Pi_1(X)$, $U_s$ is a simply-connected neighbourhood of $\gamma(0)$, and $U_t$ is a simply-connected neighbourhood of $\gamma(1)$.

name: Open Sets Equality
statement: Suppose $[\\rho] \\in V_{[\\gamma],U_s,U_t}$. Then\n\n$V_{[\\rho],U_s,U_t} = V_{[\\gamma],U_s,U_t}$.
proof:
By assumption we can write $[\rho] = [\beta][\gamma][\alpha]^{-1}$ for some $\alpha$ and $\beta$. It follows that any other class $[\beta'][\gamma][\alpha']^{-1}$ in $V_{[\gamma],U_s,U_t}$ can be written as

$([\beta'][\beta]^{-1})([\beta][\gamma][\alpha])([\alpha]^{-1}[\alpha']^{-1}) = ([\beta'][\beta]^{-1})[\rho]([\alpha]^{-1}[\alpha']^{-1})$

which proves the inclusion of the right hand side into the left hand side. The converse follows by switching the roles of $[\rho]$ and $[\gamma]$.
preconditions: map is a homotopy relative endpoints

name: Basis Verification
statement: The collection of opens described in Definition 17.13 is indeed a basis.
proof: We just need to check that intersections of two opens $V_{[\\gamma],U_s,U_t}$ and $V_{[\\gamma'],U'_s,U'_t}$ are open. Indeed, given $[\\rho]$ lying in both, we can write the two opens as $V_{[\\rho],U_s,U_t}$ and $V_{[\\rho],U'_s,U'_t}$ by Lemma 17.14, so we deduce that $V_{[\\rho],U_s\\cap U'_s,U_t\\cap U'_t}$ is in the intersection.

name: Fundamental Groupoid Covering
statement: $\\pi := (s, t) : \\Pi_1(X) \\to X \\times X$ is a covering map.
proof:
Observe first that product opens $U_s \times U_t$, with both factors simply-connected, form a basis of the topology in $X \times X$. This allows us to check that the map $\pi$ is continuous. Indeed, fix points $q \in U_s$ and $p \in U_t$. Then we have that:

$\pi^{-1}(U_s \times U_t) \simeq \coprod_{[\gamma]\in\pi_1(X,q,p)} V_{[\gamma],U_s,U_t}$,

and the right-hand side is a disjoint union of open sets $V_{[\gamma],U_s,U_t}$, proving continuity.

In fact, the topology we have put in $\Pi_1(X)$ implies that the restriction

$\pi : V_{[\gamma],U_s,U_t} \to U_s \times U_t$

is a homeomorphism. This implies that the evenly-covered property holds:

$(U_s \times U_t) \times \pi_1(X, q, p) \stackrel{\psi}{\simeq} \pi^{-1}(U_s \times U_t) \stackrel{\pi_U}{\to} U_s \times U_t \stackrel{\pi}{\to} U_s \times U_t \stackrel{id}{\to}$

where the top arrow $\psi$ is the obvious identification.

name: Universal Cover Construction
statement: Let $(X, x)$ be a pointed, path-connected, locally simply-connected space. Then $t : (s^{-1}(x), [c_x]) \\to (X, x)$ is a pointed, surjective covering map. Here $[c_x]$ denotes the class of the constant loop at $x$.
proof: We can regard $X$ as the subspace $\\{x\\} \\times X \\subset X \\times X$. Then, its preimage via $(s, t)$ consists of those homotopy classes of paths that start at $x$. This is precisely what $s^{-1}(x)$ is. Observe that, since $X$ is path-connected, every point in $X$ does have a preimage in $s^{-1}(x)$. Lemma 16.8 applies.

name: Universal Cover Topology
statement: The topology in $s^{-1}(x)$ is generated by the basis $V_{[\\gamma],U} := \\{[\\beta][\\gamma] \\mid [\\beta] \\in \\pi_1(U, \\gamma(1), p)\\}$ with $\\gamma$ a path starting at $x$ and $U$ a simply-connected neighbourhood of $\\gamma(1)$.
proof: This is immediate from the description of the topology in $\\Pi_1(X)$. Observe that $V_{[\\gamma],U}$ is one of the sheets evenly covering $U$.

name: H-related Classes
statement: Let $(X, x)$ be a pointed space. Let $H$ be a subgroup of $\\pi_1(X, x)$. We say that the classes $[\\gamma]$ and $[\\eta]$ in $s^{-1}(x)$ are H-related if there is $[\\nu] \\in H$ such that $[\\eta] = [\\gamma][\\nu]$. We write $X_H$ for the quotient of $s^{-1}(x)$ under this equivalence relation. Since $[\\nu] \\in H$ is a the class of a loop based at $X$, we see that $[\\gamma]$ and $[\\eta]$ have the same endpoint. It follows that $t$ descends to the quotient as a well-defined map $\\pi : X_H \\to X$. Moreover, this map is pointed if we take $x \\in X$ and $H \\in X_H$ as basepoints. By $H \\in X_H$ we mean the equivalence class of $[c_x]$, which is the equivalence class of any $[\\nu] \\in H$.

name: Covering Map Construction
statement: The following is a covering map: $\\pi : (X_H, H) \\to (X, x)$.
proof: Given $y \\in X$, consider a simply-connected neighbourhood $U$. As we saw earlier, it is evenly covered in $s^{-1}(x)$; its preimages are the $V_{[\\gamma],U}$ with $[\\gamma]$ ranging over the elements of $\\pi_1(X, x, y)$. Given $[\\nu] \\in H$, we see that the sheet $V_{[\\gamma],U}$ becomes identified with the sheet $V_{[\\gamma][\\nu],U}$, so they are the same open in $X_H$. I.e. the quotient map amounts to quotienting the set of sheets (very concretely $\\pi_1(X, x, y) \\to \\pi_1(X, x, y)/H$). It follows that $U$ is evenly-covered for $\\pi$.

name: UHLP for Source Fibre
statement: Let $(X, x)$ be a pointed, path-connected, locally simply-connected space. Then its source fibre $t : (s^{-1}(x), [c_x]) \\to (X, x)$ satisfies the unique homotopy lifting property.
proof: Suppose we are given a homotopy $F : A \\times [0, 1] \\to X$ starting at $f : A \\to X$ and a lift $\\tilde{f} : A \\to s^{-1}(x)$. Let us consider the paths $\\gamma_{a,s}(t) := F(a, st) : [0, 1] \\to X$. They allow us to define a function $\\tilde{F} : A \\times [0, 1] \\to s^{-1}(x)$ by setting $(a, s) \\mapsto [\\gamma_{a,s}]$. By construction, $t([\\gamma_{a,s}]) = \\gamma_{a,s}(1) = F(a, s)$, so $\\tilde{F}$ is a lift of $F$.\n\nWe must verify that $\\tilde{F}$ is continuous. Recall that the topology in $X$ is generated by evenly-covered opens, so the topology in $s^{-1}(x)$ is generated by opens $U$ which are sheets over evenly covered opens $t(U)$ of $X$. Then we see that $\\tilde{F}^{-1}(U) = F^{-1}(t(U))$ is open by continuity of $F$.
preconditions: map satisfies the unique homotopy lifting property

name: UHLP for Quotient
statement: Let $(X, x)$ be a pointed, path-connected, locally simply-connected space. Then the covering map $t : (X_H, H) \\to (X, x)$ satisfies the unique homotopy lifting property.
proof: This is a consequence of Lemma 17.21: one can lift to the universal cover $s^{-1}(x)$ and then project down to $X_H$.
preconditions: map satisfies the unique homotopy lifting property

name: Galois Correspondence
statement: Let $(X, x)$ be a pointed, path-connected, locally simply-connected space. Then the covering map $t : (X_H, H) \\to (X, x)$ satisfies $t_*(\\pi_1(X_H, H)) = H$. In particular, $t : (s^{-1}(x), [c_x]) \\to (X, x)$ is simply-connected and is thus the universal cover.
proof: This was already proven in Corollary 16.39.

name: Covering of Graphs
statement: Let $\\pi : Y \\to X$ be a covering space and suppose $X$ is a 1-dimensional cell complex. Then so is $Y$.
proof: This follows directly from Proposition 16.16, which states that if $X$ is a CW complex and $\\pi : Y \\to X$ is a covering space, then there is a unique cell structure on $Y$ compatible with $\\pi$. Since $X$ is 1-dimensional, the cell structure on $Y$ will also be 1-dimensional.

name: Free Subgroups
statement: Every subgroup of a free group is also free.
proof: Recall that $G$ being free means that it is isomorphic to $\\ast_I Z$ is free, for some set $I$. We can consider the 1-dimensional cell complex $(X, x) := \\bigvee_I (S^1, 1)$, whose fundamental group is $G$. Since $(X, x)$ is path-connected and locally simply-connected, the Galois correspondence (Theorem 17.7) applies. It follows that any subgroup $H \\subset G$ is the image of $\\pi_1(Y, y)$ via $\\pi$, for some path-connected covering space $\\pi_1 : (Y, y) \\to (X, x)$. The argument follows from the fact that the fundamental group $\\pi_1(Y, y)$ is also free, since $Y$ is also a 1-dimensional cell complex by Proposition 16.16.

name: Spheres Covering
statement: Let $\\pi : (Y, y) \\to (S^n, N)$ be a path-connected covering space of the $n$-sphere, with $n \\geq 2$. Then $\\pi$ is a homeomorphism. In particular, $S^n$ is simply-connected.
proof: Recall that the standard cell structure of $S^n$ consists of a single vertex $N$ and a single $n$-cell. Using Proposition 16.16 we deduce that $Y$ is obtained from $Y_0$ by attaching $n$-cells. Attaching $n$-cells does not change $\\pi_0$, if $n \\geq 2$, so the path-connected assumption for $Y$ implies that $Y_0$ consists of a single vertex. Moreover, since $X$ is path-connected, the number of sheets is constant, so in this case it must be one. If there is a single sheet, $\\pi$ is a homeomorphism, proving the first claim.\n\n$(S^n, N)$ is path-connected and locally simply-connected, so it has a universal cover. However, we have just shown that every path-connected covering space is homeomorphic to $S^n$. It follows that $S^n$ is its own universal cover and is thus simply-connected.

name: Circle Fundamental Group
proof:
Identify $S^1$ with $[0, 1]/(0 \simeq 1)$ and endow with the cell structure with a single vertex $0$ and a single edge $a$. We have seen that the universal cover is $\mathbb{R}$, with covering map $\pi(t) = [t]$. We can use $\pi$ to lift the cell structure to $\mathbb{R}$. It has infinitely many vertices (namely, the integers $\mathbb{Z} = \pi^{-1}(0)$) and infinitely many edges (which we denote $a_i := [i, i + 1]$).

We can now use the fact that the universal cover must be isomorphic to the source fibre $s^{-1}(0) \subset \Pi_1(S^1)$. Under this identification, $\mathbb{Z}$ is identified with $\pi_1(S^1, 1)$, since both are the fibres over $0$ via the covering map. This tells us already that $\pi_1(S^1, 1)$ is countable infinite. However, this is just set theoretically. We want to figure out that what the group operation is.

In order to do so, we let $0 \in \mathbb{Z}$ be identified with $[c_0] \in \pi_1(S^1, 0)$. Consider then the edge $a$. Its lift starting at $0$ is $a_1$, which finishes at $1 \in \mathbb{Z}$. This implies that the point $1 \in \mathbb{Z}$ is identified with $[a] \in \pi_1(S^1, 0)$. Iterating, we deduce that $k \in \mathbb{Z}$ must be identified with $[a]^k$. This tells us that the group operation is given by the usual addition in $\mathbb{Z}$, as claimed.

name: Universal Cover Nullhomotopy
statement: Let $\\pi : (Y, y) \\to (X, x)$ be the universal cover and assume that $Y$ deformation retracts to $y$. Then any map $f : (A, a) \\to (X, x)$, with $A$ simply-connected and locally path-connected, is nullhomotopic.
proof: Since $A$ is path-connected and locally path-connected we can apply the lifting criterion (Theorem 17.1) and produce a lift $\\tilde{f} : (A, a) \\to (Y, y)$. Using the deformation retraction of $Y$ to $y$ we deduce that $\\tilde{f}$ is pointed homotopic to the constant map $c_y$. Applying $\\pi$ we deduce that $f$ is pointed homotopic to $c_x$.

name: Higher Spheres Maps
statement: Every map $f : (S^n, N) \\to (S^1, 1)$ with $n \\geq 2$ is nullhomotopic.
proof: $S^n$ is simply-connected and locally path-connected and the universal cover of $S^1$ is $\\mathbb{R}$, which deformation retracts to any point.
